We sent people to set up hubs across the street from the camps and fed people their own names and asked them if they wanted to hold a clipboard or a child and listened to their answers like we might learn how to make chairs that did not splinter under weight. The angels hovered above the camps and did not sing, which is the only way to be honest around certain kinds of theater.

On a morning with cloud cover like a lid, the air over the river did a thing that made me believe in practice like a religion. The song we called Ridgetone echoed back at us with a new harmonic we had not taught it and that meant we had learned something without being given permission. I stood on the bridge that was still pretending to be a bridge and put my hands on the rail and felt the vibration move through metal that had once been ore in a mountain and now was a road and thought, If we deserve another place, it will be because of this feeling, the one that starts in the palm and moves into the chest and becomes the desire to make a thing quiet through competent motion. Velez hovered alongside at shoulder height and did not speak and I did not either because sometimes the leadership is in refusing to narrate.

We wrote new words on the wall that day because the old ones had found their uses and we needed more. We added: Ask permission even if you don’t know who to ask. We added: Seeds are also apologies. We added: No lotteries until we make sure the bowl isn’t full of only spoons. We added: The person who hates meetings the most gets to run the first ten. And, in smaller print because we were embarrassed to be sentimental in public, we wrote: Keep each other’s jackets flat.

The next rehearsal came two days later and it was worse and easier because we were different. The stars turned their wrong way and we sat and hummed and some people outside hummed louder and some sat very still and held hands with a stranger like a lifeline and the sky pretended it was not a participant. Someone tried again to sell candles and Arroyo bought them all and this time he lit one and put it on the steps and we all sat for two minutes and pretended to pray and I learned a new thing: sometimes pretending is the only way to open the real. After, a man looked at me and said, “I changed my mind about you,” and I said, “I know,” without being unkind, and he laughed like a rock being thrown into a river and apologized to the water for the splash.

When I finally took a day off it wasn’t one. I made pancakes at my place and burned three and ate them anyway because the day had been about charity and I wanted to be consistent. Jun came over with a paper bag of lemons and a dozen index cards with the word Quieter written on them because he had taken it upon himself to rename the days that used to be Saturday. Tam wore socks that did not match on purpose and lay on my couch like a person performing rest. The rubber plant had decided to become an extrovert and we applauded it quietly. Velez hovered outside like a good boundary and hummed once when the kettle boiled, which is the kind of friendship I can tolerate with the divine.

We didn’t talk about ships because if we had the day would have turned its face toward duty. We talked about the smell the ear had brought us and how it had changed our relationship to the word pine and whether we were allowed to hope that somewhere there is a tree that would not be offended by our leaning. We talked about the shoe that had hit the podium and whether we could turn that story into a warning or whether it had to stay exactly what it was: a thing that happened in a square during a speech and was resolved by laughter and a man putting his pockets inside-out. We talked about my mother and her sandwiches and how she would have wrapped every one of your names in wax paper and sent them with you and I cried and then laughed because crying is a version of cleaning and I was overdue.

When the phone rang it was a number without area code because those had stopped mattering. A voice I didn’t know said, “We found a song you didn’t give us,” and my stomach did the thing stomachs do when you are about to learn something you did not schedule. It was a farm in a state I had never wanted to visit and now suddenly would, a place where people had their own language for the wind and their own gossip about the soil. They had been playing the radio near the goats and the angels had translated the goats into another frequency because apparently you can become a conduit by accident while chewing. The song did a thing we did not expect and a thing that we had feared: it echoed inside a silo until the silo remembered it was meant to be a bell. The old farmer said, “My wife heard it and smiled without her dentures in,” and I said, “We’re on our way,” because this is how you run a world near the edge: you remind it it still knows how to make bells, even out of things it had repurposed as storage for grain.

We drove with the windows open because the van had acquired a smell like too many meetings and I needed to remember that air could be different. The road was the kind of road that turns into stories without asking. The sky did not rehearse for us that day; it minded its manners, which made me suspicious and grateful in equal measure. We passed a billboard that had been repainted to say BE NICE in letters that looked like they had been trying to be a cow and given up, and a kid on a bike shouted we’re practicing at us and I shouted back what and he shouted being neighbors and my stupid eyes filled. Tam stuck her head out the window like a dog and yelled who taught you to be so good and the kid shrugged and kept riding because it is not a mystery; people always know until they forget.

On the farm the silo did ring when asked, a deep-bell sound like a hand under a chair. The goats looked at us like we were being dramatic and went on chewing. The farmer asked me to sign his wife’s apron as if I were famous and I scrawled my name as if it meant something and then drew the small circle with a smile inside it because this was as close to a badge as she would ever want. We set up our plates and our silk and our sugar and sang the goat-translated song and the air did not change and then did, as if it were embarrassed to be caught doing a trick. The smell was not pine this time but something I could not name and later would: a resin that had been taught sadness. Dana wrote the new symbols and Kieran pressed his ear to the metal and tried to get it to talk back and it did not but it did hum, which is as rude as it is promising. Sana took the vial and looked at me and we both laughed for no reason I can tell you except that sometimes the body releases.

On the drive back, we passed a group of kids building ears out of hula hoops and old sheets and their parents watched from porches with expressions that had hope in them in a way that made me worry about the weight of our luck. Velez did not follow; it had gone to sit on a water tower and learn from rust. The radio tried to give me my own voice back through a speaker and I turned it down because I am not a person who learns from hearing herself on delay. Tam sang a stupid song about lemons to make me remember that the world remembers how to be stupid, and I leaned my head against the window and watched the trees go by and thought, not for the first time, about the word after. It had started to feel like a room that could have furniture instead of a cliff.

That night, around three, the city did the thing where it breathes in the middle of the night as if it is counting itself, and I dreamed of a green that was not grass but something new that would take my weight. I stood at the edge of a long fairway that had never needed mowing, and the flag was a flying thing that had decided to pretend to be a flag for the afternoon. I swung my driver and the sound it made was the song of a planet we had not named and I woke with my hand in the air as if to apologize to the ceiling for the noise. In the morning Jun put a new word on the wall under all the other rules. He wrote: Practice joy, and I rolled my eyes and kissed his cheek and we went to work.Chapter 7

The first time a building creased and then uncreased itself, we happened to be there by accident and also because all accidents now felt like the world repurposing our schedules. It was the train station that had been stranded since the line was cut years ago, a vaulted room with a clock face that lied one honest lie forever. We chose it for a Witnesses’ circle because it was neutral ground and because its benches remembered holding grief without curating it. We had dragged folding chairs that pinched fingers if you forgot which hinge was treacherous. Someone had laid out a table of cut oranges and cups that tasted like they had been clean and then stored near a broom. The angels perched in the high windows like a rumor the pigeons had stopped believing in. I had asked everyone to bring the object they reach for when they’re solving something, and so we had a pile on the floor: a whisk, a multimeter, a seam ripper, a battered pocket atlas, a spool of mason’s line, a dog-eared zine about breaker boxes, a needle-nose plier, a Sharpie that had survived three administrations, a coil of tape white as bone. We were telling stories of doors we had refused to be, of rules we had made inside ourselves and forgotten until now, when the ceiling briefly bowed like a person about to sneeze and the station made a sound like a hinge reconsidering its life.

You know how a room gets quiet right before someone says the inappropriate thing and then doesn’t, and in that silence you can hear chairs making tiny adjustments to people? The air did that. The pillars shivered in their paint. The floor under us gave, not in the catastrophic way of collapse but in the mercy way of a trampoline that wants to show you how to be held. Someone gasped without permission. Arroyo put his hand on his radio like a talisman and did not key it because he is learning which noises to resist. I held my breath because the instinct to freeze is embedded deep in the animal that runs my ribs. Dana whispered, “Oh, hello,” to the air as if greeting a stranger at a neighbor’s party. The door to the old ticket office opened by itself and then closed with the caution of a shy cousin. The angels hummed very low and we all heard it in our knees.

After, when the roof remembered its job and the clock remembered its lie, Holm said in a voice that had lost its edges, “Okay,” and nobody laughed because the humor would have broken like a cheap plate. We took inventory the way you do after a lovemaking that has made you weep: windows, fine; columns, fine; the poster with a smiling family from 1973 asking for exact change, still lying; Jun’s stack of index cards, scattered like good seeds; my pulse, late to its appointments and therefore present. A Witness named Lo with the anchor tattoo ran a thumb across her bottom lip and said, “It didn’t want to hurt us,” and the way she said it sounded like she had been hurt by gentler things. Velez drifted down until it hung at head-height and its light was soft enough to make me think of the underside of clouds seen from a plane aisle, and said, “The fold is practicing its handwriting. The first drafts are less dangerous when you are not proud.”

We had brought a different kind of ear, one that didn’t need a drained pool or a meta-skin. Sana had designed it while waiting for a kettle and then kept it because it was cheap and therefore likely to survive dumb hands. It was a set of nested hoops, aluminum stamped with letters from an abandoned art project, hung with sleeves of silk and strips cut from ruined shirts, a chandelier that wanted to be a fishing net. We had tied bells to it, not for romance but because the ear inside our skulls is a drum and bells talk to drums in a language everybody inherits. We hung the thing from one of the old station hooks where luggage had rested with dignity when people still wore hats out of respect fully dressed. When the room creased, the bells shivered without ringing, which meant the motion wasn’t air and wasn’t sound the way we measure either, which meant we could, if we were stupid, call it nothing. We refused that. Dana tapped the hoops afterward with the bone end of a comb and nodded as if someone had answered a proof in the back of the book.

We added a line to the wall that afternoon in a handwriting I didn’t recognize: Practice inside, it said. Then this, smaller: If the sky wants an audience, make it pay with your patience. No one admitted to writing it and everyone obeyed it because it had the rhythm of a rule our grandmothers would recognize. We started drilling people in bone song as if we were planning to field a choir against a storm. We taught breath to construction workers and toddlers and men with earnest beards and women whose nails kept clean not by care but by the chemistries they ran at their kitchens tables. We kept it unpretty on purpose so it would be memory, not spectacle. People started humming in bus shelters and grocery lines and public bathrooms devoted to hand dryers that lied about warmth. We became ridiculous and therefore correct.

The decision I had been told would find me like a letter slid under a door began sliding with an address in my handwriting. It was not the ship yet, not that made thing dreamers brawl over in drawings. It was a throw. We needed to send an instrument through the crease that had shown itself in the station and then pretended to be shy. People with PhDs were rightfully interested in equations and people with calluses were rightfully interested in whether the thing would come back, and the overlap was a Venn diagram big enough to stand in. They built a ball because balls are democratic technology. It was a sphere of lattice that looked like it had opinions about cage birds. Inside were sensors that bled numbers when poked and a core that smelled faintly like the inside of a blank tape cassette. It had velvet on one rib not because velvet helps but because Kieran had looked at the ring of bare metal and said it felt mean and then fixed it the way you fix mean when it’s in your hand.

“You could just roll it,” Arroyo said, but his voice did not sound like a man who believed in rolling anything important while the world learned to crease.

“The floor isn’t honest,” Sana said. She had measured it by feel and had written the measurements on her palm and then licked her thumb and wiped them away to write the same ones again.

“What if you throw it,” Tam said, so casually I turned and stared at her like she had been hiding her face inside a tree all morning. “I’m serious. A punch, not a full send. Low and committed. No flourish. You know that shot better than anyone.”

The room did the small cough rooms do when one job learns the shape of another job and pretends to have known it all along. I looked at the ball the way I look at a dog that has learned a trick on its own. I could see the line because my muscles had grown a map of how to make sight into physics. My hands itched with the ghost of a grip. The crease had been at shin height for a blink, a fault line in air rather than stone, a thing I could trace with the memory of the way a putt breaks near the cup when greenkeepers have been bored. I did not want to be a person whose best skill was applicable to folding realities. I also did.

We cleared the benches to make a corridor that looked like a wedding aisle if unions were for putting objects into unknowns. People stood along the edges with their hands at their sides, as per the rule, and swallowed hard the way you do when you think someone might be about to make a hole in your day. I took the ball into my hands and felt its weight and thanked some prior Rhea for chasing the kind of strength that is precision and not glory. I imagined the shot the way Coach had taught me: a movie that ends with a touch rather than a thud. I sank into my hips the way confidence does whether invited or not. I made the small rehearsal swing like a person remembering a handshake, and then I let the made piece of the world go.

It left my hand like a promise. It skimmed ankle height, a shrew running, and the air at the waist of the room became wrong just long enough for the ball to slide between one idea of where we were and another. For a second it wobbled, a glitch that made my throat go tight, and then it disappeared the way a coin disappears when someone skilled has palmed it and you are in on the trick but not on the muscle. A woman near the end of the corridor covered her mouth not because she believed it would bring it back but because sometimes the hand knows what ritual is needed and the brain will learn it later.

We had put a string on it because we are assholes and also because this is how you tie yourself to fate without admitting you’re doing it. The string whispered across the floor and then went slack then taut then slack again like a cat thinking about jumping onto a counter. We all flinched in the same direction because pack animals still reside in us. When it rolled back under the bench I thought I might vomit because I did not want its answer. The lattice was dusted with something that made a rim like the ring in colin’s mug. It was not ash. It was too simple to be ash. I did not recognize it, which is how you know you are alive; if the world stops showing you new white powders, it has given up. Sana extended a small brush the way mourning extends a hand to the door frame and coaxed a drift into a vial and made three more vials like she believed in redundant mercy.

Kieran sniffed the ball because men with math will still sniff first when we aren’t watching, and then he laughed that noise he makes when a puzzle gives up a corner. “Salt,” he said, not triumphant, not disappointed, just naming. “Nothing earth salt knows how to be. A salt that hasn’t tasted our oceans. A salt that doesn’t like our ways of being water.”

“The bunker,” I said, and everyone made a face at me because my metaphors had been tolerated but not embraced. “In my dream,” I added because sometimes you submit evidence you can’t prove because it wants to be next to the other evidence to feel like a family.

We argued without drawing blood for once because the rule on the wall had begun to breed in us. There was a quick, ugly discussion about whether we should lick the salt. We did not lick the salt. Sana did the three simplest tests again because a genius repeats the small true things until they become furniture. It dissolved slower than we like. It made a smell like a library taking its socks off after a long walk. It did not fizz like disappointment. Dana wrote a symbol that looked like a ladder down a page that already had too many ladders. The angels did not advise. Velez watched me in the wary way good teachers watch the moment a student realizes they are about to be asked to go on a stage they can’t see yet.

After the witness circle formalized itself around what we had done, the room began to do what all rooms do now: it turned into a hub by stealth. That is, it sprouted tables with sign-in sheets, a box for lost items, a corner where one kid drew on the floor in chalk and nobody told him not to because his lines were better than tape. A woman with two first names ran a pot of coffee that smelled like something we no longer sell and regulated everyone’s cup with the authority earned by running a coat check when winter meant something. We used the station for the first meeting we had avoided having: the not-quite-list of not-quite-rules for how to choose where to build more ears.

“Bus lines first,” I said, and Holm smiled as if I had just remembered a friend’s birthday without being reminded. “Hubs need to be reachable without a car because the future can’t hear engines whining any louder than we already make them. The people nearest the water that thinks it might be a wall. The buildings with chairs already inside them, not because chairs are special but because chairs are a language doors speak. And stop me if I sound like a stack of clipboards pretending to be a human.”

“You sound like a human in a clipboard hat,” Dana said, which is the kind of insult that in this house lands like an arm around your shoulders. “Also the places with bathrooms people won’t be ashamed to use. Dignity is a mouth that doesn’t open, but it keeps people fed.”

“Put ears in places with a reputation for rumors,” Arroyo added, surprising himself. “They’ll keep an eye on it for free because they can’t bear not to know. It’s a sin we can use that isn’t a sin if the sign-in sheet is honest.”

“We will need power without wires,” Sana said, eyes flicking to the ceiling as if power hung above us like ripe fruit. “Human-crank. Small turbines where the gutters like to shout. Bikes that work smarter. Remember how to get a friction match to behave. We’ll need a maniac who will cure their obsession by making us a better battery.”

“I know three,” Jun said, not smug because he doesn’t know how to be. “I’ll bribe them with snacks and the ability to name something they did not invent.”

I made a speech I hadn’t rehearsed because no one would let me go write it, and it came out as a list of particularities because the generalities feel like stealing. I said, “Put one in the barber shop where the father and son fight kindly on Saturdays. Put one behind the dance studio where the floor knows names. Put one near the daycare that won’t call itself a daycare because it knows the word makes some men feel weird about paying women. Put one in the senior center that smells like bingo markers and lies told without harm. Put one in the old parking garage where the reverb is good because it accidentally teaches you how to listen.” The angels brightened the way I have learned means thank you and apology and promise all at once, and I put my hands on the back of the folding chair I’d been standing behind because Donna, the woman who ran the coffee, had put her purse on it and I imagined her finding it later intact and liked the picture of her face.

We convened a Witness council without a table and without minutes and it still worked because Vincente brought markers in colors that looked like juice and wrote on butcher paper like graffiti. The names on the wall became a constellation that made a path if you squinted. Barber. Zipper-fixer. Librarian. Soup-line. Anchor-wrist. Lightning tech. Teen with humming radius. Bus driver with a rosary made of fuses. It felt like making a team out of an orphanage when the orphanage was run by the orphans.

My phone buzzed against my thigh, the insect of obligation, and I stepped away into a hall that smelled like old tile and decided not to answer because the corridor had that old building echo that makes every voice sound like it’s from thirty years ago. Velez followed because it’s learned that hallways are where humans admit the thing their mouths can’t do in front of a bench. “You could have been a violin maker,” it said, a door opening on a story I hadn’t planned for.

“Because my hands pay attention,” I said, and put my forehead against the cool paint of the pillar because it had been keeping people up so long it deserved a kiss. “Or because I like to fix what makes a tone.”

“Because you are patient with a thing that refuses to be rushed,” it said. “Because you do not take a tool to a grain that will not like it and call that leadership. Because you could have spent your whole life listening to wood remember tree and you did not, and now you are listening to air remember water.”

“Tell me another thing I don’t want to know,” I said, and immediately regretted it because every time I ask for that kind of hurt something important is delivered along with a bruise.

“We cannot go,” it said simply, and its light did that dimming that now felt like the lowering of a gaze. “We are made of your dark. We do not belong to the places we will tell you the songs of. We can hover and sing and warn and ache. We cannot be citizens there. We are a technology of witness, not a species for export.”

“You’re stuck in the play you helped direct,” I said, not unkind because I had seen this face on a hundred mothers and on myself. “Is that why you used the word forgive in public and didn’t flinch.”

“We do not deserve the pronouns we use,” it said. “We say we because it feels like a coat that lets us walk around in daylight and that is a lie we will be chewing forever. We have been made into a choir when once we were the thing that eats the audience. We will not be rewarded with applause. We will be asked to sing as you walk out. It is fair. It is unbearable. Both.”

I do not have the right to be the person who comforts a being that used to thirst for my blood, and yet here we are; we are always comforting the wrong person because the right person is busy. I touched the air two inches from where its shoulder would be if it had one and felt a heat like a lamp on a kind of almost-skin. “You can come to the hubs and sit in the rafters,” I said. “You can stand over the insulin and hum like a refrigerator. You can terrify only those who deserve it.”

“I know,” it said, and if light can swallow once, it did. “We will build your ears and guard your ears and fight your mouths with our shame. We will do none of your choosing because you would die under our choosing. We will hold your jackets flat.”

We went back into the station and the meeting had become a potluck without food. Everyone was putting up offerings: a schedule here, a car with a trunk there, a nephew who made drones out of parts that had never met. Dona from the soup-line had taped a sign to a pillar that said COOKS, and under it three names and two phone numbers and a little smile face that gave me more courage than angel light. Arroyo was teaching a teenager to say no to authority by letting him practice at him. Holm had cornered a councilman who had arrived with a suit and a face like stern pie and was explaining to him the difference between oversight and hovering; he looked like he was learning, and I did not take bets. Sana had used a shopping bag to make a sling for the lattice ball because people kept cradling it like a baby and I couldn’t stand watching them rehearse a nursery.

That was the day the blowout-hair man tried to own a hub with a camera. He arrived on the station steps with a crew that moved like it had learned ballet in rooms with poor tile and the word exclusive on a board. He said my name the way a dentist says cavity. He asked to tour the ear because taxpayers and oversight and chain of command when applied to air. He held a microphone in the way a child holds a bug: anticipation and disgust. I did not step outside because if I had my body would have makes shapes my mother would have told me to save for the mirror. I sent Jun with a stack of clipboards and a lemon. Jun handed him a clipboard and a pen and said, “Write down what you will do for us besides speak,” and held the lemon up to the camera and said, “This is our current symbol for people who help. You can hold it if you want.” There is a clip of his face taking in citrus and failing to turn it into rhetoric, and I keep it on my phone for the nights I want proof that symbols are only powerful if they stick to skin.

We wrote the No Mouths pledge on the back of an old train map that still showed a lake that had become a park. It started as three sentences and then grew sentences around their hips like children holding on to mothers’ legs. We put a swear in it on purpose so people would feel like it was theirs and not a grant proposal. We made everyone read it out loud who wanted to stand near an ear for longer than a song. Some people rolled their eyes and read it anyway because they wanted to be near a miracle. Some people read it and cried at the fourth line and then pretended they had a cold and we pretended not to notice. We taped the pledge next to the sign that said BATHROOMS and people read both with equal attention and I don’t know anything that made me happier for a full hour after.

That night, tired thicker than soup, I went back to the course with Tam because the station’s air had filled me with iron filings and I needed to become a magnet again. The floodlights were off because electricity is now something you ask permission from and I am trying to become a person who does not assume my yes is the first one. The fairways were silhouettes, wider at night like people who soften when nobody’s watching. The bunker on seventeen lay where it always lies like a love that had been useful and then mean. We lay on our backs near the tee and looked up with the decision to see nothing but imagined stars even if they were doing the wrong thing. Tam pointed and told me a different kind of constellation: that’s the one that looks like the bus stop where we met the woman who had the cat in her hood; that’s the one that looks like the pile of shoes at the gym door after the sky tried to argue with us; that’s the one that looks like your face when you said the word planets and didn’t faint. I laughed, then hiccuped, then choked a little, then laughed again, and thought, if joy were on the schedule, it would never get done. You have to sneak it into the notes someone left on the break room fridge.

We launched the first not-ship a week later, and it wasn’t a ship because we had kept our promise to ourselves. It was a moth made by stubborn hands, a raft for air, a kite with a chordal heart. The kids named it Moth because they are accountants of poetry and I want them in my government. It was a skeleton of rods and mesh the color of the inside of a seashell, with a belly full of ears and a spine that whistled when the wind got fresh. We built it in a school gym that had given up learning dodgeball and taken on learning humility. Jun made a checklist that ended with the line breathe. Lo drove it on a flatbed through streets that had learned, embarrassingly quickly, how to make room. People came out and put hands flat on its ribs because touching is how we make contracts we can’t afford lawyers for. We rolled it onto the roof of the station because the sky had been rude there and because lifting a thing toward its work is ceremonial whether you want it to be or not.

The angels did not bless it because we are trying not to become a place where wind has titles. They stood three stories up in the air the way a good parent stands at the end of a diving board and puts their hands out without expecting a child to fall toward them. We held the lines like you hold a friend’s hair when she is sick. The wind did what wind does when it is being watched and remembered its if, and we waited, which is the part that feels like weakness and is actually the muscle. When it took, it took clean. Moth rose without dramatics and our breath went with it and then came back because the rule on the wall had started becoming blood. It shivered where the air had creased a week before and didn’t shatter, which taught me a new word from inside a word I thought I knew.

The data it sent down was less important than the message it sent our bodies, which is a sentence I will have tattooed one day if the world gets back its habit of making people do silly things with needle and ink. Numbers are love letters written by different kinds of mouths and we will keep them, frame them, argue about them, make new instruments just to be able to talk back to the parts that looked us in the eye. What mattered was watching a thing we made stand in a wind we didn’t invent and not apologize. What mattered was the way the kids on the roof grabbed each other’s hands without making a show of it, the way Arroyo said copy to the air and meant thank you, the way Holm didn’t check her phone for a full three minutes and then checked it and laughed because a councilman had texted her Are the angels unionizing which meant we had won a different small war.

We had our first theft that week, and it did not come with the anger I’d rehearsed for. Someone stole thirty vials from the freezer labeled with numbers I had learned like hymnals. We discovered it because the freezer door, which had been screwed up from a police auction and then unscrewed back down by a grandmother who knows where to kick, had been left open ajar enough to make the motor complain. The list on the whiteboard had a smear where the row of numbers lived, not frantic, deliberate, the work of a person who believes in erasers. We followed the line of sugar water drip that had been knocked over like a person too tired to be careful, and it led to a back door and then into a morning that smelled like eggs cooked in a pan without love.

We learned the thief’s name not because we’re detectives but because this is a city and names are communal property, and when you say “she had a scar like a comma by her mouth and a way of carrying a bag like a shift,” someone will say, “Allegra,” and then five minutes later Allegra will be at the door because she has better hearing than most. She cried with that quiet experienced kind because this was not about her remorse; it was about her tiredness. She had built a mouth in an old laundromat with a boyfriend who wanted to marry her before the fold or die trying, and the mouth had been good at lying about its charms. They had poured a song in with a funnel they stole from the back of the bar and an air popped and her boyfriend had said he could see the other side and then couldn’t because it wasn’t a side and he had gone down like a man remembering a hole he’d made in a field as a kid. She brought the vials back in a cooler that used to have a marlin on it, and I thought about punching her and then I thought about how much I had loved someone I was going to lose once and didn’t, and I handed her a sandwich. Velez stood in the corner like a judgement we had all decided not to invite and did not speak, which is its new way of honoring us.

We wrote a new line on the wall that day in a slant hand: Forgive the crimes that come from practicing badly. Punish only the ones that come from selling tickets. Holm made a face and it wasn’t because she disapproved; it was because it had the cadence of a rule that would get her yelled at by people who value the word consequences the way some people value lace. She signed off anyway with the line one uses when one is about to get yelled at by people who eat steak in rooms with wide tables: “We’ll do the reasonable thing and call it extreme.” I kissed her cheek and she threatened to revoke my privileges and we both laughed because it was the kind of fake threat you make to the people who are holding you up while you pretend to hold them up.

There is a photograph somewhere I hope no one ever sees because its beauty would get it framed by the wrong people: three angels hovering over a line of kids pulling on a rope attached to Moth while a woman with a baby slung across her asleep like a limp question holds a clipboard and a cup of coffee and does not spill either. The sky in the photo is a sky the fold has put on to make us complacent, all syrup and tender. If I had to make a monument to exactly what I want to bring to wherever we go, it would be that rope and those hands and that cup stabilized by the muscle memory of care.

We started losing sleep on a schedule you could put in an app if anyone could stand inventing another app. Dana’s ears got sharp around one in the morning; she would show up with a hoodie inside out and a piece of metal clamped in her teeth to chew. Kieran turned into a person you could only talk to by writing on his arm and he would look down and find your sentence and then answer you in a sketch that looked like it had already been in the air for days. Sana laughed more and it scared me how much I wanted to bring her tea because tea is the only thing I can make that pretends to be professional. Arroyo stopped wearing the rank jacket altogether and built a little shelf by the gym door for people to leave their rings on while they carried water and his hands got used to handing back gold and silver with the kind of respect churches used to teach. Jun got two white hairs that he looked at in the mirror like prizes. Tam learned to sleep in chairs like a man on a train with his head tipped forward and his mouth open and no concern for his own dignity because home had been relocated to the corner of a table.

The night the moth came down in a new way, the wind wasn’t bad. That’s the thing I have learned that I keep wanting to put on billboards and can’t: most days now will not announce themselves as big in the way your body expects big to show up. We had two lines on it, one literal, one the string that goes between a group of people when they’re doing something dumb carefully. It had been writing numbers down its tether as if Xs were love letters and we were gossip mongers with stacks of stationary. Then it stopped writing and we all looked up like bad dogs. It drifted sideways the way a person drifts at a party when they are done being polite. The mesh hummed in a bad key. Nobody shouted because the station remembers what shouting is for. Lo and Arroyo and two school custodians with matching shoulders walked to the edge the way you walk to the edge of a lake you’re going to jump into because your cousin dared you, calm, breath like a man counting the paces of a driveway. They hauled hand over hand and the rope came in with a wobble that made my teeth chatter because my body loves the wrong things. When the moth came over the lip, it smelled like pennies and then like peach skin and then like a chandelier that had tried too hard at a wedding. We set it down on blankets and went on with our lives because the best way to make something unmagical in the good sense is to put it on a blanket and hand it a cup of water.

Five days later a school sent us a gift that made me think we might be able to become the kind of people who deserve gifts. They had found a way to tell a town that the sky was rehearsing without triggering fear so intense it would get in the way of the smaller duties. The announcement was a sound, and then a color on phones that had a battery, and then a chalk mark on a door that had no electricity and still could be read as easily as a book. It was three lines long and written like a diabetic’s shopping list: stay in; breathe so your bones hear; sing if you must. We laughed because they had stolen our line and then we sent them bread because stealing is the sincerest form of food. The blowout-hair man tried to trademark Stay In and was told no even by the people who like to say yes to men with watches. It was a stupid victory. I put it on the wall anyway.

I thought the first big fight would be obvious, a man with a speech and a banner and a flag he had ironed. It came as a woman with good teeth and a smile that had convinced people to buy vitamins. She came to a hub with a crew and did not go to the ear or the insulin or the sock table. She went to the line where we were matching people who hate meetings with their first ten meetings and said loudly that we were going to put people on lists. She said we were going to put stickers on doors. She said the word loyalty like it had ankles she could grab. She used my name like a game piece she was moving on a board she’d brought. People looked at me and I looked at my hands because if I had lifted them the words would have been ugly.

Tam laughed once, not loudly, but with the clarity of a bell in a station. She walked to the sock table and held up a sock, the ugliest one because it had a cartoon that had not aged well. “We’re putting socks on feet,” she said, and the room turned toward the true thing because the true thing had been held up like a flag. “We’re putting water in buckets. We’re putting kids in circles where they can hum without the sky noticing. If you need a list, you can have one; it will be shopping. It will say lemons. It will say tape. It will say dignity.” The crowd laughed and then applauded and the woman’s smile turned into the kind you put on when you lose at monopoly, and I remembered to breathe because Tam had handed me the rope again without making me feel less for needing it.

We wrote a kinder rule on the wall that night because the mean rules were breeding too easily: Give people a job they can finish in an afternoon. Don’t let them go home with a list that spans months. Feed them or they will eat their fear. Holm added in small letters, Pay them if you can in money, not coupons, and I hugged her around the shoulders and she stiffened like a person not used to being touched casually and then allowed herself to melt in stages until it was over and she didn’t have to acknowledge it.

I got sick, which is not heroic and also a plot device I resent, and which happened because bodies are rude. It wasn’t a sky sickness or a fold cold; it was the old friend who shows up when you’ve been sleeping in a chair and licking stale coffee off your teeth. Fever hung from me like a necklace I couldn’t unclasp. For two days the hubs ran without me, which is how I learned that a good job is one where you can vanish and the thing continues. Tam sat beside the couch reading a manual about pressure cookers in case we needed to sterilize instruments and every once in a while read a line aloud and I would laugh and cough and then say, “Don’t let anyone build a mouth,” and she would say, “We put that in the code, you are not that special,” and I would sleep again. Velez stationed itself across the room like a lamp that could ward off thieves, and Jun wrote on my wall in pencil and then erased it when I complained about the mess and then wrote again because he knows me better than I do.

On the third day the fever snapped like a bad string and I woke to the sound of brooms on a gym floor and Sana telling someone to hold the funnel less like a weapon and more like a promise. The window showed a morning that was pretending to be ordinary and I made coffee with my hand shaking and spilled half of it on my notes, which felt like a blessing if you have ever been the kind of person who wants to ruin her own writing so she can move on. The map by the plant had grew new lines that I hadn’t drawn, and I didn’t ask who had added them because the point of a map is not ownership. It is consent.

We took the Moth out again that afternoon to get it back on the horse it didn’t know it had fallen off and because sometimes our tools are more anxious than we allow. The angels made themselves small, which is their signal they intend humility, and the sky was a kind of blue that had just learned to miss something. We sang the song for Ridgetone like we were family who had learned to be on time for once, and the ear tugged against its lines and then lifted the way my heart lifted when I heard a particular laugh in a crowd. A child asked if the fold would be mad if we used it and I said, “I think it is a door learned by a hand; it likes to be useful,” and the child said, “I don’t like being useful,” and I said, “Me either, but the pay is good if you mean sleep,” and he looked at me like I had not earned that joke yet and went back to counting knots in the rope.

We started a newsletter because the part of me that wants to be a librarian will not be silenced entirely, and called it Buckets & Bells because acronyms are banned and also because any other title would have been an apology. We printed it on paper because phones are luxury pets now and because paper travels through hubs like water. We put lists in it that mattered and stories that kept those lists from acquiring the over-seriousness of a memo. We published the recipe for the chaotic pie Mrs. Davila makes when the room has been too righteous and she is under orders to put jam into adults and a crust on their tongues. We published a cartoon of an angel holding a jacket flat and people cut it out and taped it next to their hooks and I went into a stairwell and let my knees do the thing they do.

Toward the end of the month that cannot be named anymore because the months had given up their loyalties, the sky rehearsed at noon. It was worse because people were in the middle of tasks that could not withstand interruption without becoming humiliation. A woman carrying a stack of trays remembered that she had once dropped a stack of plates in a restaurant and been yelled at so sharply she had gone to the bathroom and thrown up and learned then how to keep her hands steady when catastrophe wanted to have sex with shame. She did not drop the trays now. Men on a scaffolding sat down like they had been made ninety suddenly and grinned at each other as if they were finally allowed to admit fear was a warm animal and not a snake. A boy put his finger on a page in a book and did not lose his place, and I wanted to put that in a museum that would still be standing when this was over.

We made a library of smells at Sana’s insistence because she is the only one among us who knows you cannot build a ship without building what it will think is food. She tacked strips of cloth on a board and labeled them with numbers and grimaces. Resin taught grief. Lake taught forgiveness. Meat tried to pretend it had never hurt anyone. Bread came from six kitchens and we kept them separate because merging good things too early is how you make them into a paste. We collected dust from under a hundred beds and found trace elements of shame and sex and sleep and decided to catalog all of it because ships will need to know who we were and because catalogs make people behave. We taped the board next to the ears on the wall with a line that said nose training because there is nothing wrong with being exactly what you are.

That night a priest and a woman who claimed to be an exorcist and a scientist who builds quiet fans got into a fight about whether the fold would appreciate a blessing, and I hid behind a stack of chairs and pretended to be a chair. The debate got not stupid but loud, and the angels dimmed in the way we have come to understand as their version of rolling their eyes. The exorcist said a word in a language my body recognized and winced, and the scientist said drag coefficient five times and made gestures in the air that I swear moved a breeze, and the priest said a sentence so kind it made me suspicious of his knees. We blessed the Moth because refusing to bless a thing is how you make a hole in a room that drafts. We blessed it with caution and seasoning salt and a line drawn in chalk so no one would walk under the line and be mad about superstition later. It came home that night smelling like the page of a book you have kept pressed to your face for just a second too long and I thought, we are all learning how to hold.

When I write “we have a plan” now I mean we have a plan like a person has a recipe written by a grandmother who eyeballed everything and refused to tell you the oven temperature because she knew you would learn from the way the kitchen smelled. We have ears and we have hubs and we have one moth and we have a pledge and a broom schedule and a No Mouths wall. We have lines on maps that are being redrawn by a river with new ideas. We have a woman who tapes up the flyers that say HUM PRACTICE and also a woman who comes to tear them down because she hates singing and I am glad she exists because voices like hers keep us from becoming a cult. We have angels who cannot go and a list of names of people who will. We have a shoplifted cooler and a freezer indicted and redeemed. We have stolen sleep and stolen lemons and a boy who told me my jokes were not yet earned. We have an old station breathing again and a golf course that lets me count the times I have been made to stand still and survive it.

We do not have ships. We do not have a perfect way to choose who will go first when the time comes. We have trial runs and prayers we will not call prayers because labels are expensive and I am saving money. We have the first call from a small town on a coast I used to think of as vacation that says the water came up the street and did not knock. We have the second call from a hospital that says their windows are making a friend of light and is that bad, and our answer is yes and also excellent, can we visit. We have my mother’s sandwich in my mouth like the memory of salt and we have my father’s measuring tape running across a table the size of seven kitchens put together, and somewhere inside both those truths is a place big enough for a moth and small enough for a hand.Chapter 10

By the time the air learned to be hot again, the city had a choir of hammers. You could walk three blocks with your eyes shut and name what kind of building you were next to by the pitch of the knocking: low for stages disassembled and repurposed as shelves, bright for sheet metal turned into frames, fussing little taps for the kind of work that needs fingers more than forearms. Buckets & Bells started printing on both sides of the page, which felt like evolution and thrift at once. We declared the next seven days No Mouths Week and the kids made chalk circles outside every ear room with the pledge written around them in letters that ran out of space and doubled back like small brave snakes. The rules wall in the gym had begun to look like the inside of a teenager’s locker, all stickers and authority, but it worked better than anything else we had: you could point at Dignity and then point at the stack of paper gowns and people would take the gowns without rehearsing shame.

A stadium out by the river that had been empty since the team left became a dry port without anyone announcing it. People rolled in from the spine of the state with their trunks full of seed and their mouths full of news and their backs full of ideas about distance. We called the kits that left that place hearths because calling them packages made people imagine coupons and we needed kitchens. Each kit was a careful little list in a crate: a crank that didn’t mind wet hands, a bell tuned to a note that made people stand up without wanting to fight, a binder labeled with handwriting you wanted to trust, a tarp the color of hope if you had never seen the ocean, and a sleeve of stitched meta that had learned to be humble. The best part was that by the time the second batch went out, they came back with additions we hadn’t ordered: a scarf woven by a grandmother that made the ear behave better in wind; a whistle someone had carved from PVC that worked only when held by a left-handed person and thus became everyone’s favorite; a recipe stapled to the inside cover for beans that tasted like wealth even when nothing in the pot could be counted as fancy. I watched the kit move from our hands into hands that had calluses I had never earned and felt the relief that is letting go without dropping.

City Hall tried to create a box to keep all this inside and to their credit the box was at least transparent. Holm called it a Civic Commons Charter because she knows how to make a thing sound inevitable and kind at once. It was a handful of promises written without commas and three sentences forbidding the exact kind of theft we had seen attempted in suits and in prayer shawls: no ownership of ears; no privatizing songs; no putting a ribbon on angel light and calling it brand. A councilman with shoes you could shave in gave a speech about oversight as if it were a vitamin you need to crush into applesauce to tolerate, and Holm said over the top of him, not shouting but with that tone she keeps in a pocket, “We are not deregulating kindness.” We signed in the station because paper matters still, and then we put the signed paper on the wall where anybody could draw a mustache on it if they wanted, and nobody did which felt like a small miracle in a city that used to live on graffiti.

The fold came to a hospital like a rumor that walked in the front door and paid at the desk. It was noon, which felt like an insult because everyone had jobs at noon. The elevators stopped in between opinions about floors. A gurney drifted sideways as if the ground had changed its mind about left. The new ear room we had wedged into an old chapel took the hit like a good aunt, all open arms and low humming, and people who had been taught to keep feelings outside tools put their palms against the silk so their bones would make the sound travel the right way. The windows whispered, a sound like paper prep in a classroom, and every nurse in the place thought about the night they had been handed a tray for the first time and been told not to tilt. A man died, not from the sky doing theater but because his heart had been practicing to leave anyway, and we stopped everything we were doing and learned how to do funerals without making a false shape out of loss. We wrote on the wall later, in a corner where grief could pretend to be private, Funerals will be human even when we are busy. We will say names. We will not turn anybody into a motto. We will feed the mourners cake they do not have to thank us for.

Moth came back twice with salt and then once with a powder that wasn’t salt and made Sana sit down, which is a more reliable measurement than anything she could have written on a board. The new stuff made a soft clinking noise when you breathed too near it, as if there was an inside that wanted out but remembered itself in time. Under the scope it looked like small cities that had planned their own suburbs with better taste than ours. Kieran suggested, in a voice that he didn’t trust yet, that this could be the shape of oxygen finding something to live with, and we stood around and waited for the air not to betray us with the smell of false hope. Sana did the idiot-proof tests first because she is an angel by practice and a scientist by job: she put a leaf near it and the leaf didn’t curl; she put a flame near it and it didn’t leap; she put her own curiosity near it and it snapped at her and she smiled and wrote don’t trust, then later wrote trust enough to try again. We wrote a new line that felt like a prayer we could admit: We might not need domes if we learn to sit with the weather.

At home the pressure cooker made a sound like a building that knows its purpose and is satisfied. Tam learned to talk to the hissing the way she talks to me when I am about to bolt: with patience and laughter as if neither were hard. She made a stew out of what the hub had left, which means it tasted like generosity and cumin, and she watched me eat it like she was checking for leaks. We spoke about after as if it were a town we had been to as kids and had to find on a different map. Jun came in with hair like a good idea and a spreadsheet he had printed so I could look at it without screens. He had made a gift matrix because he is the only person I have ever met who believes that gratitude should have columns. It asked questions like who did you thank this week with your mouth and who did you thank with your hands and who did you avoid thanking because you think it will make them ask for more. He stuck it to the fridge with a magnet shaped like a tomato and I loved him with the kind of suddenness that makes you want to run a lap around your own apartment to get rid of the extra electricity.

The blowout-hair man opened a pop-up with lights and tried to sell admissions to a mouth built behind blackout curtains. It was in a warehouse that used to make fake snow and now made memory problems. He called it The Way and if I’d had the energy I’d have sued his graphic designer for crimes against meaning. A teen took a photo and sent it to Lo and Lo sent it to the group thread with a picture of her anchor tattoo and the words not on my route, and ten minutes later Arroyo and two door people and a cluster of aunties arrived to stand in the doorway and do the steady stare that makes even men with clipboards admit their mothers taught them better. A man in a hat told us we were suppressing innovation and I said, without raising my voice, “Jukeboxes are innovation. Doors that swing one way are traps,” and the auntie with the best earrings wrote in lipstick on the loading dock in letters as tall as shame: No Kings. We repainted it later, not because anyone told us to but because the statement deserved better paint.

Velez came to the station and stood so still you could mistake it for sculpture, which meant it had learned it would be listened to without arranging a scene. It said ships must be shaped like agreements, which made me laugh because I had been part of organizations that treated agreements like shoes. It said not arrows, which landed in me like a stone I would want to pick up and hold. It taught us a word, not in our mouth language, more in the way that breath learns the sound of its own threshold: sleeve. Not a tube. Not a gate. A soft length of listening we could keep open for six seconds without anything alive in it and then ten, and then maybe a minute if we were people who remembered to be small. We said the word in the station and the bells on the ear made a sound that sounded like the corner of a laugh.

The first sleeve was the color of the sky when a bruise is thinking about itself. We built it in the station where the ceiling had learned to ask a question. It was stitched by six women who had never met before that week and now shared pins like recipes. We hung it from a rig that Lo’s bus barn had donated after someone used a correct mixture of sincerity and cookies, and the rig had the good sense to confess its limits. The sleeve hung like laundry, which made me want to cry because I could not stand how domestic the apocalypse had become on its best days. We did not put anything through it except air and then a stream of scent and then the sound of the song which is also weight. We held the rig while the sky did its tiny training pushups. The sleeve tightened the way we do when someone we don’t know walks too close. The smell that slid back was not lake and not bread and not anything in our library. It was the smell of a page just before you turn it when you know the next paragraph will hurt and you keep going anyway. We wrote Sleeve behaves, Day 1, and then we went home and slept as if we had a teacher.

I started telling people no more often, which I suppose is what happens when you are asked for a full-time yes. I stopped going to the meetings where people wanted me to bless their plans with my eyebrows. I started showing up at places where my body would remind me why bodies are the first technology we learn: the barber shop that had grown a phone-charging station out of a shelf of aftershaves, the laundromat where the exorcist had taken a night job and folded socks in pairs as an act of mercy, the diner where the coffee had started tasting like it used to because a kid had gotten good at cleaning the machine. In each, someone would hand me a note to tape to the wall or a lemon or a clip for my hair that had a piece missing and I would hold the broken thing and say thank you as if the thank you were glue.

Holm got yelled at by men who had never learned to find their daughters at a hub without a map and I watched her take the yelling with the face you wear when you’re waiting for the water to boil and someone else is trying to tell you which bubble is legal. She stood on the stairs at City Hall and told a man in a hat who wanted the word loyalty written large over the doors to the hubs that the word neighbor had more letters and more hands in it. She took a call in the stairwell about trucks we needed to move refrigerators we had borrowed from a closing ice cream place and I saw her smile a smile I will never forget because it was how a person looks when the world finally matches the list they have been keeping in a pocket for a decade. I brought her tea with a wedge of lemon because Jun was on a campaign for citrus and she drank it without remarking on my attempt at ministering and then said, “Do we have a plan for babies,” and I said, “We have ten,” and truthfully we had four and a half and a woman named Bee who had found a way to sterilize bottles in a crockpot and whose name made me feel like we were going to be okay.

There was a day when every dog in the city barked for thirty-seven seconds and then stopped and sat down and looked guilty. We wrote it on the wall under a heading called Animal News and then we watched for anything else that had a rhythm and the only thing that matched was that every dishwasher that still worked in the city hiccuped the same hiccup at the same time. We decided to not anthropomorphize dishwashers out loud in public and then did it in the stairwell anyway. Sana circled the time on her chart and drew an arrow to a dip on a graph that made my stomach do a reasonable thing: it refused to turn into story. We have learned to only story after counting and I wish that were a habit I had learned earlier in a different life that did not require so many people to stand still in gyms while their bones learned to sing.

We took Moth out with candy in our pockets because we had finally admitted that small sugar at the right instant turns certain men into the children they used to be and makes them better at ropes. A second sleeve went up and the sky did not insult our work with calm; it pushed just enough to examine our stitching. We braced and did not perform. I thought about my driver like a talisman and put my hands in my pockets so I wouldn’t reach for it and make a scene. The song of Ridgetone turned in the sleeve like soup and came back thicker and I watched three teenagers look at each other and decide they were going to live long enough to make new harmonies even if they never left the ground. We do not brag, we put our hands on the rig and say thank you without choosing a subject.

News came from the coast that had once been for postcards. The water had taken a street without knocking, and the hub had done the thing it is designed to do if we tell it to: it became a porch. The ear hung near the ceiling and sang in a key the town had not practiced and the town hummed in a key it had, and between those two truths the folding did not break anybody that day. We wrote a new line on the wall in the hand of the woman who had called it in: The porch is a science. We underlined it twice because it felt like a sentence the future was going to come back to and ask us to explain with chairs.

The first real bad, the kind with teeth, came wearing our own handwriting. In a neighborhood that had beat us to building an ear they also built a schedule and then they fell in love with their own clipboard. They started refusing people who could sing because they couldn’t spell pledge. Someone taped a sign that said MEMBERS ONLY and I went very still in the way that tells me I am about to be mean if I don’t swallow. I did not go. Lo went, because Lo has the voice mothers recognize as equal and the patience of a person who has driven a bus through five types of weather. She stood with her anchor wrist and her binder and said, “No one can trademark humming,” and then she read our charter out loud in the slow voice you reserve for bedtime stories and traffic court and by the third sentence a man with a badge on a lanyard started to cry because badges don’t fit in mouths and his tongue knew it. We wrote, later, in a different color, Don’t become your own border.

A scientist three time zones away sent us a new instrument she had built out of shame and copper. It listened for pressure shifts and spit out numbers like rain and I learned to love it because it didn’t make any sound itself: humility you plug into the wall. She wrote in her note, in tiny letters I had to borrow a teenager’s young eyes to read, Our fans keep lying to us about drag; yours tell the truth; keep the truth. I built her a small altar in my head next to my mother’s jar of sugar and my father’s tape that never ran out and put on it a piece of ribbon from the sleeve we had retired when a stitch gave up and we patched it with a bandana. I do not know if this is prayer. It felt like the only way to say thank you to a person I had never touched.

We were asked to speak to the world on a day that smelled like the library and I put my head down on my kitchen table because I could not stand the idea of being a mouth that big. The request came without an ultimatum and with a time window inside which everyone had agreed to stop yelling. We decided the sender was either a genius or a person who’d had one good experience with silence in a yoga class and tried to give it back to the planet. Holm wanted a draft in case a microphone failed; Sana wanted three numbers to anchor it so the sky would know we weren’t trying to seduce it; Jun wanted an index card with the words water, buckets, dignity, lists, no kings; Tam wanted me to wear the hoodie and not the jacket because people trust fray more than polish. Velez wanted nothing and that felt like the greatest generosity of all. I wrote on paper I had spilled stew on because I wanted the words to sit inside something that had fed me and if that isn’t ritual I don’t know what is. I wrote, Hello. I am a person. We have a plan, and then I wrote, Our plan is a verb. We need you to build a room for later people. It will smell like bread and resin and the first day of a school where the teacher looks at you like a name instead of a seat. Bring buckets. Bring bells. Bring a neighbor who hates this. We will be there first and last and in between. I crossed out three metaphors and kept two and went to wash my face.

The night before, the neighborhood practiced joy because it was on the schedule and I will die on the hill that scheduling joy is the only way to guarantee it happens. The gym turned into a dance not to forget but to remember that bones can move in ways that have nothing to do with fear. An angel held jackets flat from the rafters and I tried not to love the sight too much because I am trying not to become sentimental in the face of cosmic apology and failing in moderate ways daily. The sleeve hung from its rig like a line of laundry not yet taken inside because the weather was behaving like a parent after a meeting with a teacher. The fold made a small wrinkle overhead and we hummed and the wrinkle passed and no one bought a candle at a markup, which is how I measure maturity in a populace that has learned to forgive itself a few times without turning that into a hat.

I slept with my driver under the bed on purpose because I wanted to feel ridiculous and domestic at once, and my body knows that feeling is the only door to sleep left to me. In my dream the fairway that is not grass opened into a field where women were laying sleeves on the ground like quilts while kids ran their hands over the seams to learn what it means to trust a stitch. The flag was not a bird that day. It was a handkerchief with a recipe written in my mother’s handwriting and an apology written in Velez’s light, and both of them made a kind of sense I can only experience when I am lying down. I woke at five to the sound of coffee in someone else’s kitchen and the city did the slightly embarrassed shuffle of a person who has been caught practicing something tender. I stood at the window and watched the sky not break and took that as a blessing even if it meant nothing. Then I wrote on the wall, quietly so as not to wake the others, Sleep is what we give in exchange for tomorrow, and underneath it, the smallest letters I am capable of, Practice joy.

The morning they turned, I was watching a tee shot hold the wind like a kite.

It was early, that not-quite-blue hour that golf people hoard like misers. Dew on the fairways of the municipal course out past the river, maintenance guys muttering, a distant herring gull scissoring apart a take-out box. I had the place to myself except for Tam, who wore her wool cap over a too-messy bun and held the shag bag like it was a reliquary. She’s been my caddie since before the tour, before my first sponsor, back when my shoes were unstitching and my wrists were raw with tape. She knew the arc of my drives better than I did. She knew when I was going to top it by the way my jaw set.

“Listen,” she said, as the ball climbed and climbed, catching an angle in the cold air I hadn’t seen before. “Hear that?”

“I hear a five-iron doing what it was told.”

“No,” she said. “Some kind of… choir.”

I tilted my head. Nothing but the low hum of the highway, the mosquitoes that never slept, distant dogs arguing with their own chains. And then, like a whale surfacing in a dark sea, sound. A draped shimmer, an organ pipe bent around itself. Not in the air, though. Inside. My skull bones ringing. A long, braided note that felt like peppermint on a cracked lip.

The ball hung and hung, then descended in a way that made Tam, who hates poetry, say, “That was like a moth. Like it decided.”

“Wind shift,” I said. “Thermals.”

The note unspooled into other notes, thin silver threads. Tam dropped the shag bag. She put both hands to her ears, eyes gone bright and wet. Twenty miles away, I learned later, a man kneeling on a cheap laminate kitchen floor still wearing his fast-food visor began to weep and couldn’t stop. He had been dead for nineteen years. He was a vampire.

There had always been vampires. Not the old story: cloaks and crumbling castles, not velvet-lined coffins bought at estate sales. Ours were ordinary. They used bleach. They cut their hair with kitchen scissors. They paid for parking and fought with their phones. They left you alone mostly. Not always—once, long ago, in desire or hunger, they had not. But by the time I was a teenager they were part of the weather. They worked double shifts. They sat on bus benches and read the same paper as us. They smelled faintly of old coins and rain.

The choir happened at 3:16 a.m. in some countries and at lunchtime in others and at exactly in the middle of your nap wherever you were, because that’s how fate arranges itself, with rudeness. Every vampire I’ve ever known fell to his knees or her knees or their knees. They shed their bodies like jackets and rose into a light that made noise. I say rose, but it was less physical than that, more like they remembered a note and chased it up. Held together by mathematics and grief, they were new things. Not winged men. Not cherubs. Not anything that would fit inside a church painting. They were angles and brightness and attention. They were angels because we needed a word.

We called it the Turning because we turn things that change—soil, pages, faces toward the light.

The first one I saw came from the pro shop. He had been working there for years, a quiet, mostly-silent man named colin in lower-case because he hated his name and refused to give it the dignity of capitals. For a decade he’d measured out soft spikes and glove sizes. I brought him muffins on Mondays because I suspected he had no one else who did. He had been a vampire, though I didn’t know that then, until he crumpled behind the counter, the flimsy plexiglass register guard trembling after he was already not-there. What rose from him was a geometry of light that touched the ceiling, the racks of branded polos, a jar of tees with tongue-in-cheek slogans I never bought. It touched me. On my right cheek. The way my mother’s hand used to, absent and exact, while looking the other way toward a pot on the stove. Its touch was a measurement, a line from me to some unknown apex. It burned just enough to wake up a piece of me that had been drowsy all this time.

Tam said, “Rhea, your face.”

“What about it.”

“You’re lit like you’re radiating from inside out.”

“I’m not,” I said, but I was.

“I didn’t think he was one,” she said, looking at colin’s holiday mug, last year’s cabernet shopping list in his half-printed half-cursive stuck under a magnet shaped like a golfing koala. “I didn’t think any of them still were.”

“They’re not anymore,” I said.

We walked out under a sky that had become a bowl of ringing notes. People were emerging onto their porches, some in slippers, some tugging at their sleeves as if to wake up. A maintenance guy dropped a rake that had been patched with duct tape. The head pro, gray-bearded and unapproachable as a granite hill, stood in the doorway like a picture of someone waiting for a bus that would never arrive. All over the river and the city beyond, pinpoints of rising light. On the news a woman tried to keep her eyes on the camera while looking past it at something above her that made her mouth make an O and stay that way.

And in that shimmering, in the glissade of breathless hours after the Turning, the old maps curled and peeled and there was a new, impossible atlas beneath. The club members, the early risers with their range tokens and their complicated wives, knelt experimentally, as if praying would please the new weather. A teenager vaped and forgot, smoke pouring like a small personal fog as he stared upward. In the corner of the putting green, a cluster of six angel-shapes hovered like a bouquet of night-blooming plants. They didn’t touch the ground but the grass under them was pressed down as if by a good, heavy snow.

It smelled like ozone, like fresh water poured into old holes.

“Don’t go near,” Tam said. Her hands were fists in her pockets.

I did, because I had always lacked that part of the brain that believes warnings are anything other than metaphors. A bright figure uncurled toward me. When they talk about angels in old books, the writers often get shy and resort to obscurity. I used to think that was because the writers were cowards; now I know it’s because there aren’t words for some of it. This one had an outline, if by outline you mean the idea of an outline, and the idea suggested was “human.” A suggestion of shoulders, a suggestion of teeth that were not teeth. A brightness that would be searing if you hated yourself, but if you didn’t, was bearable. In that brightness a shadow like a bruise moved, slow as a cloud.

“Rhea Moss,” it said, although it didn’t speak.

I nodded as if to a starter before the horn. Because when a new thing has your name in its mouth, you nod. You pretend you expected it.

“You used to—” I started.

“Yes,” it said. Or sang. Or arranged the air so that yes was what I heard. A voice like a hole cut in the fabric of a lie.

“What do you want,” I said, which was not what I meant. What I meant was, Who are you now. What I meant was, Is this why you liked watching me putt. What I meant was, Do you love me.

“I was called Velez,” it said. Not its real name, of course. A name used like a shirt. The vampire I had met once in an alley behind the course seven years before. It had been a hot night and I was waiting for Tam to return with the car. My second-hand bag was leaning against the dumpster. The alley belonged to grease, to two green-tinted fluorescent lights, to the dumpster lid that never closed all the way. Velez had stepped from behind an exhaust pipe as if unspooling from a smell. Tall then. Narrow face. Bleached hair done badly. Thirsty eyes, but controlled, like a dancer watching whose hand holds the blade. He had said, “You swing like you can hear things.”

“I can hear my coach yelling inside my head,” I’d said. He had smiled without teeth. He had watched me for a while and then said nothing and then, with the exact sadness of someone leaving the opera before the last act, he had left.

“It was you,” I said now.

“It is I,” the angel said.

I hadn’t had enough coffee for this. My palms itched. In the pro shop, colin’s mug still steamed with whatever tea he liked. Outside, a woman in black leggings stopped mid-run and lifted her hands to the air, as if to catch a ball no one had thrown.

“This is… good,” I said, because a person needs a stance at the start of a very long, very strange day.

“This is not simple,” the angel said gently. Every light in it quivered. “We are not what people think we are. The word will help, and also it will not.”

Tam clanked a club in the bag, a little warning. She does that when she wants me to retreat. A code we’ve developed like birds. The angel turned its attention to her without looking. Her cap trembled.

“What do you want with me,” I said again, being the sort of person who repeats the true question awhile until it gives up its secrets.

“Your game is a way to talk about other things,” Velez said.

“That sounds like a fortune cookie.”

“You aim at quiet and you make it with motion.”

“You’re getting weird,” I said.

“Everything is odd, now,” it said, almost apologizing for the world.

Angels were filling the day like a tide. On the television in the clubhouse, somebody had turned on the news and it showed footage of a hospital in Nairobi where a nurse screamed and then knelt and then laughed, showing a gap between her front teeth. In front of the hospital, an angel hovering near the jacaranda tree turned the purple blossoms into a cascade of honey bees, but the bees did not sting. They spelled something in the air in a language only the tree understood.

Tam said, “We should go.”

“Go where.”

“To your apartment,” she said, as if it were a fort.

I watched another angel tilt itself toward the river, light sliding off the water, making everything too real, cruelly precise. “We can,” I said, but I didn’t move.

Velez—no longer Velez but for convenience we used the old shirts we had—folded more brightness around itself until it looked less like ten thousand prisms and more like one thing. “There is a set of questions that will rearrange themselves around you,” it said. “Stand there. Let them do the rearranging.”

“Am I supposed to do something,” I said.

“You are going to have to decide something that no living person has decided,” the angel said. “But not today. Today put the clubs in the trunk. Drink water. When you talk, do it like a person who remembers the ground.”

“Decide what,” Tam said darkly. “Decide between what and what.”

The angel lifted its non-face toward the treeline as if listening to a far-away train. “Heat,” it said softly. “Cold. Staying. Leaving. There are planets in need of names.”

I laughed. It wasn’t a pretty laugh. It was sharp and too loud in the morning air. “We can’t even land a par on the third when the wind is up,” I said. “Now planets.”

“You are a person with a driver in your hand who understands distance,” the angel said. “You are a person who has stood in crowds and not lost the thread of your own breath. That is a kind of leadership. It’s the beginning of one.”

“I’m a golfer,” I said, suddenly angry for no good reason, because that was the thing I was and I had made peace with how small it was. “I hit a ball with a stick and then chase it and hit it again, and sometimes people clap because the angle of my wrist is consistent over time. That’s all. Don’t turn it into a metaphor to make me feel better about this,” I said, and surprised myself by sounding like my mother, who never got the hang of the internet and had made peace with that too.

Velez’s brightness dimmed and then deepened like breathing. “It will not feel better,” it said. “And we are not here to philosophize. We cannot lead you. You would not survive our leadership.”

“Then why talk,” Tam said.

“Because we can tell you where not to step,” it said, and for a moment there was a shadow in it like old shame. “Because we can sing to you about what we did wrong.”
