Across the fairway, a tall shape moved. At first I thought it was the head pro finally coming to tell us to clear out, that even in apocalypse there were things to be done. But it was a woman in a dark suit, shoes ungrassy. She hurried toward us with a face like the sky right before hail.

“Moss?” she said, out of breath.

“Yes,” I said, because I was still me.

She held out a badge that meant nothing to me. Script letters, a seal with a ship. How many seals we invent to keep ourselves from drowning in each other’s doubt. “Minister Holm,” she said. “Interim… Well. None of that matters. I coordinate the city’s emergency response.”

“That must be going well,” Tam said, because fear shortens her fuse and sharpens her jokes to needles.

“It’s not,” Holm said. She was sweating through her collar. “You were named.”

“Nobody named me,” I said. “I had a nickname once, but—”

“Just now. On Channel 4. On God knows how many channels,” she said. “In a statement made by—” She looked sideways at Velez, and her eyes did a strange thing, a hardness like a skin pulled tight over them. “By one of those. It said your actual name. It said to begin by finding you. It said, ‘Tell Rhea Moss what we told you to tell her.’”

“That’s an absent pronoun,” I said, as if that was the point.

Holm’s mouth made a line. “I have a team. Scientists. Linguists. A person who studies—” She gestured helplessly at Velez. “My sister is at St. Agnes and she has not stopped crying since five-forty a.m. Also one of my dogs is floating four inches off the tile and won’t come down. We are not okay. Will you come with me. Please.”

Tam stepped forward, between me and Holm with the ease of a guard. “To do what,” she said.

“To be debriefed and then briefed,” Holm said. “To ask questions. To listen. To tell us what the thing told you five seconds ago.”

Velez made a sound like a bell shaken and then gripped in a hand. “Go,” it said to me. “I cannot protect you on the ground. But I can stand nearby in the air. It’s not nothing.”

“You mean you can hover and look majestic,” Tam said.

“Among other things,” it said mildly. “We are newly made. We do not understand our limits yet.”

“Come on,” Holm said, and for a moment I saw past the minister to the person who had eaten toast this morning quickly, without tasting, while the radio mispronounced its fear at her. She had a faint glitter at her collarbone, sweat or tears. I’ve never liked being told what to do. But I also know when first practice is over and it’s time to tee off.

I tossed Tam the keys. “Bring the bag,” I said. “All of it.”

“All of it?”

“Even the putter I hate.”

“You hate all of them at some point,” she muttered, but she hoisted the bag and followed.

We drove in Holm’s car, a black thing with too many dials, through a city we knew but didn’t. Clouds threw themselves apart. People were hugging at crosswalks. A man pushed a piano from a storefront onto the sidewalk and played it very badly and with great seriousness, as if to see if music still worked. Above us, angels flickered like strange birds in a storm. In the rearview I watched one dip low over a nursing home and then lift, and as it lifted, several windows opened at once from the inside, hands reaching into the air as if it were velvet, as if one might catch a bit and keep it in a drawer.

“What did it say,” Holm said into the windshield.

“It said my name,” I said.

“I heard,” she said. “After that.”

“It said I should drink water,” I said, because the least important things sometimes feel like the anchors.

“I can get you water,” Holm said, and we all laughed, the brittle kind. I looked at Tam and saw that her eyes had that wild wetness I fear: the one that means, If you try to leave me, I’ll turn into a map of your leaving and thus you will never be lost and thus you will always be wrong. I nodded to her, the kind of nod that says it all without explaining anything: stay, go, breathe, I don’t know.

We arrived at an ugly building that had been ugly before the Turning and would be ugly after any apocalypse. Inside was a room with a table, and in the room were people who looked like they had not slept and were brimming with more words than they knew where to put. Dr. Sana Ortega introduced herself while putting her hair up with a pencil. Her eyes were like cut wood. She shook my hand dryly and didn’t let go too long. “You were named,” she said, as if we both needed to practice saying it.

“We keep saying that,” I said.

“It’s the kind of day where we repeat nouns,” she said. “Sit. This is—” She pointed: a linguist named Dana who wore earplugs although it was quiet; a physicist who introduced himself as Kit and then immediately corrected that to Kieran and then laughed as if that mattered to how matter behaves; a city council person who had been recently promoted without wanting to; a priest who was not in collar and whose eyes were red rimmed; two interns who looked like they’d grown three inches this morning.

The screen on the wall showed faces from other rooms. This is the decade of faces being rectangles stacked in other rectangles. They looked at me too hard. I looked back because that’s a skill you learn when people look at you to figure out who they should be.

“Okay,” Sana said. “Tell us. Don’t worry about whether you’re making sense. The truth will sort itself. It usually does, not fast enough.”

I said nothing at first. I was thinking of the first time I held a driver as a kid and realized that this was a stick that could erase and invent.

“It knew my name,” I said. “It said we’re going to have to ‘decide something no one alive has decided.’ It mentioned planets. It told me to drink water.”

“Planets,” Kieran said. “Plural.”

I nodded.

“Do you think—” Dana started, and then put a hand in the air. “I’m going to ask it badly. Do you think they mean we should see other planets, like tour them, or that we should live there.”

“Colonize,” the priest said grimly, and then flinched at the word as if it had bitten him. “Is that the word we’re using again.”

Sana leaned forward. “We knew something was coming,” she said. “Other than this, I mean. Seismic weirdness. The glacier data. The slow roll of ocean heat. There have been nights lately where the stars looked—wrong. Or too vivid. Or too arranged.”

“Or like the paintings you’d see in dentist offices,” Dana said. “The ones with the wet road at night and just a little bit of tail lights—” She looked abashed at the analogy. “Sorry. There’s no real language.”

“If everything is still, it’s only because the mechanism has become a wheel,” the priest murmured, as if reciting.

“They told us,” Holm said, and her voice hopped like a windy umbrella. “They told us on the broadcast that the Earth is ending.”

“Define ending,” I said, and heard my own voice sound like a hollow object.

“I’d like to,” Sana said, and rubbed the pencil through her hair and made a mess. “In how many days, months—? They were very bad with the number. The number was spoken and then sung and then shown as an image of a hand closing and then as a shadow moving across cress. We’re translating across forms. But roughly. Roughly. Two and a half years.”

“Plenty of time,” Kieran said, and then covered his mouth. “I’m sorry.”

“Apology accepted as soon as I figure out who is owed it,” Holm said.

We sat there. Sometimes the sitting is the work. Tam, at the back of the room, leaned against the wall and stared at the ceiling like she could see into the floor above. I thought of my apartment’s plant, a rubber plant that refuses to die, proof that some things like neglect. I thought of my mother, who used to stand in the kitchen after doing the dishes and stare at nothing, not because she was contemplating death but because if she put down the dish towel she would not know what to do with her hands. I thought of a map of the night sky pinned above my teenage bed, a poster someone gave me free at the planetarium that I kept because it glowed.

“Why me,” I said. “I’m nobody. I’m good at something that mattered yesterday.”

“You don’t really think that,” Sana said. It wasn’t a question.

“I don’t not think it,” I said. “I’ve worked my whole life to be good at playing a game. That’s not nothing. But it’s also not telling a million people where to put their bodies so they don’t die.”

Tam said, “Maybe they don’t want a leader who likes pointing. Maybe they want someone who gestures.”

In the corner of the room, as if called by being discussed, a softness brightened, and Velez entered without using the door. Holm flinched, and then pretended she hadn’t by adjusting her shoe. Sana took a deep breath in and out. I watched the intern’s face do the kind of joy that makes you suspicious of your own bones.

“We cannot say you are nobody,” Velez said. “That would be an unkindness to language. You are Rhea Moss. In certain games people whisper your name like a place they went once that they didn’t want to leave.”

Nobody moved. The building’s vents hummed a low, tired note. Outside, a siren tried to keep doing the job it once had.

“You would like us to choose someone else,” Velez said, its voice almost amused. “You have never wanted the microphone.”

“I don’t like microphones because they make my own voice sound like a person I would not follow,” I said.

“I can’t lead the world,” I added, hearing the absurdity and wanting to hold it like a pet. “I can’t even finish a round sometimes when my own breathing goes weird.”

“You can because you must and you will hate it,” the angel said. “But hate is not a disqualifier. Sometimes it is a kind of faith.”

Sana glanced at me with eyes that flickered like candlelight. “If this were a movie,” she said, “this is the scene where you say no three times and then fate conspires to yes. But I don’t think this is a movie. I think we all have to be wrong and keep going.”

“What do the angels want,” the priest asked Velez. “Really. Not the soft version. The sharp one.”

“To be forgiven,” Velez said without hesitation. The room exhaled, a sound like a seabird giving up. “To witness. To sing so a thing doesn’t happen. It’s an ugly word. A folding. The world will crease along a line we cannot smooth.”

“What kind of line,” Kieran asked, for whom lines were everything.

“Imagine paper,” the angel said. “Then imagine it learning about wet. Then imagine a hand wanting a boat without knowing how to float. It folds. The paper is still paper. It is a boat now. But the water is the law, and law is not sentimental. We cannot force the float.”

Holm made a sound, not laughter. “That was approximate as hell,” she said. “But I understood it anyway.”

“Good,” Velez said. “We will be imprecise and we will still arrive at true.”

“So planets,” Sana said briskly, pulling us back from metaphor like pulling a dog from a river. “Do you have coordinates. Are there ships. Do you carry them inside your—” She gestured at the angel as if there might be a pocket.

“We have the songs of places,” Velez said. “Think of them as addresses. We do not have ships. We are the opposite of a ship. We resist shape.”

“We have rockets,” Kieran said, then winced. “I mean. We have… a few. We have budgets that were not approved. We have plans with corners missing.”

“We have nothing,” Holm said, and this time it was not despair but the bluntness of someone taking stock.

“Not nothing,” Tam said from the wall, and I wanted to kiss her for that. “We have hands. We have people who go out when it rains with buckets and try. You can do more than you think if your shoulder remembers the angle.”

“This is insane,” I said, finally. “No one is going to listen to a golfer.”

“They will listen to you because we say so,” Velez said, and I hated the way my stomach roiled at the thought. “That is the worst reason for someone to listen, but sometimes it is the only one that works long enough to find a better one.”

Later, after too many forms were printed and then abandoned, after an intern brought me water in a paper cup and cried when I thanked him for a small thing, after Sana scrawled on the whiteboard until the pen squealed, we went back to the course. It had become a place people came to because they needed a place to stand. The grass had never been so trampled by sneakers. Someone had set a bowl of fruit on the starter’s table, as if to feed a god. The angels huddled in groups, superficially like birds at a pond, actually not like anything at all.

Velez hovered over the seventeenth because it is a hole I have always loved: a dogleg with a stupid bunker that bullies me. Evening came down the way a parent comes down the stairs after a too-long silence: suspicious of joy. People sat on their heels or their hope. The tree line stood still. A woman with a baby at her chest rocked and hummed, and the baby watched her mother’s mouth out of the corner of his eye, as if it were the moon.

On the tee box, the air changed pressure. If this sounds like a lie, it is because language doesn’t have braille for it yet. Ears popped. The hair on arms shook awake. Above us assembled a shape that was a choir. Not one angel, not fifty, a formation like a swarm caught in decision. They made a low sound and it scraped gooseflesh up spine bones and all the memories that lived there uninvited.

They said, without sound, in a way that made children hear it as lullaby and scientists hear it as a data dump: We have been made new and we are not your judges. We have been made from your dark things and our dark things and we will pretend not to be bad at pretending. We have three things.

One: A sentence that cannot be unmade. The world will fold. You cannot stop it with repentance, with money, with a clever hinge. Some of you will think you can. That thought will be useful, briefly, in that it will produce energy. Harness it with kindness. Do not let it turn you cruel.

Two: Songs of other places where your bodies could learn to breathe. We cannot guarantee a life there. We cannot guarantee anything. We can tell you where the ground says yes when paired with the right boots.

Three: Names. Names are how you begin. One of the names is Rhea Moss.

I wanted to look behind me and see if there was someone else. Wanting that was like wanting backward rain.

They called my name a second time and the sound of it made me an infant and an old woman at once. Time buckled. I thought of the first time I read the rule book and realized the rules were less about behaving than about agreeing where the lines were so we could invent them again together the next Sunday.

We will speak to your leaders. We will not choose them for you. We will not stop your wars. We will sing outside the door while you wrestle and bribe and cry and cut and forgive. We say the name so that the room remembers a different shape it could take.

The baby at the woman’s chest hiccuped as if something delighted him. It was absurd. It was perfect.

Someone behind me said, too loud, “She plays a game,” and someone else said, “Exactly,” and it made my throat close.

Velez drifted nearer until the brightness washed my hands and made the veins in them map-blue. I imagined every blister I’d ever had, all the small pains that had kept me awake at night, and thought, If all the pains in the world were put in order from smallest to largest, where would mine live. The answer did not matter. But asking was a kind of worship.

“We will give you the song now,” the choir said, and they poured a sequence into the air. It was at once a sound and a temperature. It smelled like the inside of a clean ceramic mug, like wet bark cut by a pocket knife, like pennies and peach skin. It was coordinates if coordinates were a lullaby. Later, Kieran would sit with it and transcribe and cry and then wipe his face and laugh and then cough, bent over, as if clearing a pipe. For now it was just the feeling of a far-off lake in summer where the mosquitoes had agreed to leave you alone one blessed evening and you didn’t question it.

I understood nothing and everything. The green trembled under my shoes. The bunker waited with its old patience. The angels finished. The crowd did not clap. We stood in a silence that was not silence; it was something packed, a held breath in the body of the city.

Then everyone did the thing you do at weddings, at airports, at funerals. They began to speak at once about practicalities that had nothing and everything to do with the biggest thing. Did you bring sunscreen. Does the bus even run now. How is your mother. My phone is dead. Where will we put the people who had planned to be buried when the ground is planning to be water. Do you believe any of this. I can’t feel my teeth. No, it’s fine. It’s fine. We will remember how to be good.

Tam tugged my sleeve. “Hey,” she said softly.

“Yeah,” I said. My voice was lost somewhere between here and tomorrow.

“I don’t know how you’re going to do this,” she said. “I don’t even know what the this is. But I know I’m going to be there when you do it or don’t.”

“Don’t do that,” I said, trying to smile. “You’ll end up giving speeches and you hate microphones more than I do.”

“I’ll stand behind you and hold your jacket so you don’t do that thing where you hunch,” she said, and she made the shape of the hunch with her body and for a second we were just us, and the word planetary didn’t have anywhere to land near our shoes.

The air smelled like rain though the forecast had been clear. Every forecast would be wrong now, permanently.

At home that night, my sibling Jun called. On the screen he looked like a face that was trying not to be a face: eyes smudged, hair with that roof-lift look of someone who had been running their hands through it. He is younger than me by seven years and he is, often, smarter.

“Rhee,” he said. He calls me that when he wants me to know he is in the room emotionally even if he is not. “What is happening.”

“Something big and something little,” I said. “None of them our fault.”

“I cried in the grocery store’s canned beans aisle,” he said. “A woman I didn’t know handed me a lemon. We both looked at it like it was a bomb and then laughed. Is this what we are now.”

“I think we have always been also this,” I said. “Just less lit from the side.”

“You’re on the internet,” he said. “You’re a meme. They’ve photoshopped you into every painting with an angel. Even the ugly ones.”

“I’m spectacular under oil paint,” I said, because it was the smallest joke I could manage.

Jun swallowed. “They picked you.”

“They said my name,” I said truthfully.

“You can do it,” he said, as if what it was were a party trick. “You practice in the rain.”

“They want me to help everyone move house,” I said. “It’s a big house.”

Jun’s face did a thing like he had breathed in too much night air. “Mom would have—” he began and stopped.

“Mom would have made sandwiches,” I said. “Big ones. And then worried about the mustard stain.”

“I’ll come,” he said. “I’ll— I don’t know what I’ll do. I can make spreadsheets. I can drive. I can fetch. I can hold water while someone drinks it and not make it about me.”

“Be safe,” I said, which is the lie we tell because we need the shape of it between us and the cliff.

After we hung up, I sat at the small table that was not designed for destiny and put my head down on its warm, soft wood. The rubber plant leaned toward me like a bad actor and then remembered to be a plant. Out the window the city did what cities do: flickered between panic and joking, between siren and shuffle, between singing and sleep. Somewhere, someone was making a chart with a pencil that had a bite mark on it. Somewhere an angel was telling a child that none of this was a punishment, though some would want to make it one. Somewhere the men who had always loved weapons were polishing them with the kind of care they never gave their own bones.

My phone pinged with a message from an unknown number:

My father says hello. He was a patient of yours. At night. By the range. He says your swing made a sound he thought he’d never hear again. He says thank you. Also. He says sorry.

I put the phone face down on the table and watched the little light pulse for longer than was useful. The angels were above the city in their assembly language. The golfers of the world were arguing in comment sections. The dogs were confused. The cats were pretending it had all been their idea.

It would be a while before I slept. And when I did, I dreamt of a fairway as wide as a desert and a flag made of starlings and a bunker filled with salt. In the dream my father, who had never cared for golf because he thought it was for people who had too much time, stood beside me holding a measuring tape that unspooled and unspooled and never found an end.

I woke to the sound of morning news like always, except the newsreader’s voice broke when she said the word ordinary. The city’s mayor had made a statement; it had said exactly what statements say and nothing of what they mean. The President had tweeted and then deleted the tweet. A preacher somewhere had told his congregation that they were chosen because they had prayed louder than other congregations and then his wife had hiccuped loudly into the microphone and the choir had laughed and the laughing had saved them from themselves for four minutes.

The angels at dawn made a shape over the river that was maybe a map and maybe a warning. Velez hovered outside my window like a bad idea or a brave one.

“Well,” I said into the glass, my breath making a cloud that vanished too fast. “Here we go.”

“Here,” he agreed. “We go,” and then he told me the first of the songs again because I had forgotten it already, and because forgetting is the ocean and remembering is the shore and you can stand between them only for a while without being changed.

People knock on doors when they are asking for signatures to get onto ballots. They knock on doors when they are selling magazine subscriptions you forgot were still a thing. They knock on doors when they have come to ask for help or to apologize. That morning the knock on mine was careful, no urgency, no apology, and it said: opportunity, inevitability, both.

I opened it to find Minister Holm holding a stack of papers and a pen that had viscera on it from being bitten. Sana was behind her with a thermos that said COFFEE in a documentary font. Tam leaned in the hallway like a guardian whose sword was sarcasm. And over them, like a lampshade on the very idea of us, Velez.

“We need to write a speech,” Holm said, swallowing. “And by we, I mean you.”

“It can be short,” Sana added, because she is a blessing. “It can be just: Hello. I am a person. We have a plan.”

“We don’t have a plan,” I said.

“We will have one by the time you get to the words about the plan,” she said. “Start the sentence. The sentence will grow around it.”

I looked at the papers and saw that all of them had my name on them in typefaces that tried to be serious. “Do I have to wear a suit,” I said, and for the first time since the Turning I heard my own voice sound like I liked it.

“You can wear exactly what you were going to wear,” Tam said, and I looked down and saw that I was wearing the hoodie with the frayed cuff and pants with a grass stain that had refused bleach like a stubborn saint. “It’s not a fashion show. It’s the end of the world,” she said, and then caught herself. “I’m sorry.”

I nodded. “Don’t be,” I said. “True things don’t need apologizing, just handling.”

And that was how it began. Not with trumpets. With a tee time no one wanted but which, having been found on the schedule, we could not ignore. With a woman from the city who had given up on her dogs touching the floor and with a scientist who believed that if you put enough graphs under enough light they would become a hallway. With my caddie, who knew when my hands were lying. With an angel who had once taught me how not to be afraid of my own wrists in the moonlight. With paper. With water. With a small word at the start of a large sentence, and with the knowledge that there were planets in the dark with our possible names hanging over them like unripe fruit, that someday maybe we’d bite into and wince and keep eating anyway.

I wrote the first words down. I crossed them out. I wrote them again.

Hello. I am a person. We have a plan.

Chapter 3 started at my kitchen table because every epoch starts somewhere graceless, with crumbs and a ring of coffee left by a thermos that promised eternally hot and delivered almost. Holm spread the papers like a card trick she didn’t believe in. Sana set down her thermos and unscrewed the lid with that scientific precision that makes you trust a person with hard news. Tam stood behind my chair, arms crossed, using posture like armor. Velez hovered in a way that would have been theatrical if theater had ever been that specific about light. The rubber plant leaned toward the scene, performing curiosity. I had slept an hour and a half and it had been full of numbers without units.

“Say it like you mean it,” Holm said, as if meaning were something you could pour into the hollow of a syllable and trust it to set. “Say it like you are not asking for permission.”

“I am asking for permission,” I said. “From everybody. To be in their heads with my voice for five minutes.”

“Then ask like you know they’ll grant it,” Sana said. She slid a pen across the table and it made that soft whisper that pens make when they want to be useful. “We can’t script a day. We can script a first breath. Start with the small words. They hang better.”

I wrote, slowly because speed feels like lying when your hand isn’t sure, Hello. I am a person. We have a plan. The words looked like they’d been caught in the act of being, half naked. I stared at them until they were just shapes and then I looked away so they could be words again. Tam reached over my shoulder and tugged my hoodie hood so it lay flat and didn’t make me look hunched. Sometimes her caretaking irritates me the way gravel irritates an oyster. Sometimes it makes pearls out of my day.

“Tone?” Holm asked the ceiling, because sometimes you ask a roof for what you want from a crowd. “No miracles. No beautiful suffering. Practical hope.”

“If I talk about buckets,” I said, “will they think I’m making fun.”

“If you don’t talk about buckets, they’ll think you’ve never been to a flooded basement,” Tam said. “Say the thing with the word that fits in a coat pocket. Nothing with wings. We’re full up on wings.”

“Tell them the number,” Sana said quietly. “Not the precise one. The true one. Two and a half years is a long time and no time. They need to feel both.”

Velez dimmed and brightened like a creature remembering that it was also an equation. “Say that we will be wrong,” it said. “Say that wrong is a path if you keep walking and don’t build a house there.”

I wrote that down even though I hated it. I hate it when a thing that sounds like a fortune cookie is also the only thing there is to say.

We argued about the third paragraph the way you argue about whether to take a five iron or a six when the wind is doing a small dishonest thing. Holm wanted a list because lists calm people who are addicted to chaos. Sana wanted a story because stories give chaos a chair. Tam wanted a promise that we would not build a fence and then only open it for the prettiest. I wanted to stand very still until the responsibility slid off my shoulders like rain. Velez wanted us to explain that angels would not be in charge under any circumstances because power loves a costume and theirs glowed too much.

“Tell them about the hubs,” Holm said finally, the word coming out as if it had grown teeth on the way. “Schools. Gyms. Churches. Community centers with roofs we know the names of. If you tell them where to go tomorrow, they’ll sleep tonight.”

“We don’t have a plan for those yet,” I said.

“We do by the time you say the word hubs,” Sana said. “We have a hundred clipboards and a million hands. That is plan shaped. The rest is hinges.”

We practiced. Practice is how I have tricked my own fear for years, making it believe it is seeing the thing twice when it is only seeing the thing once with a rehearsal stitched to it. I stood beside my kitchen counter and held a wooden spoon because microphones are just fancier spoons. Tam made me pause between sentences the way she makes me breathe over a putt. Holm timed me with a watch that looked expensive and cheap at once, like a politician. Sana filmed and winced and then said the word good as if it were a rare material. Velez did not speak, which was also a kind of speaking.

They took me to the municipal building that had always pretended to be a temple without being one. Steps. Flags. A broad square that had seen protests and farmers’ markets and a meatball tasting contest that went to fistfights. The air had a clarity that scared me. There is a way the day looks when something has just died, even if you can’t yet say what. The square was newcomers to dawn: people holding handmade signs that did not demand so much as offer. WATER, one said. LISTEN, said another, as if it were a verb we could press into bricks. Someone had drawn an angel in sidewalk chalk and given it roller skates because kids know everything and spare you the explanation.

The platform looked like a cart without wheels. There were microphones clustered like flowers around a grave. Cameras perched like too-interested birds. Holm whispered to someone with a clipboard that looked like a passport to a place you wouldn’t want to visit. The Mayor shook my hand and the shaking was actually a network of twitches that made a rhythm of panic through bone. A man with a priest’s face but a carpenter’s hands stood near the edge of the stage and looked at the crowd as if he’d been asked to count them and couldn’t because they were not rocks, they were water. Tam squeezed my shoulders, one then the other, in our old pattern: left for the body I have, right for the body I think I have.

I stepped up and the crowd made the kind of sound crowds make when they don’t know if they’re about to be entertained or sent home. I put my hand on the wooden edge of the podium and thought of the grain of a driver, the way wood still remembers tree even when it’s pretending to be equipment. Above us the angels had arranged themselves in a configuration I refused to call a halo. It was more like a mobile hung by a nervous parent over a crib, slightly off-center so it would spin slow.

“Hello,” I said, and I made my voice walk instead of run. “I am a person. We have a plan.”

There is a kind of hush that is not silence but a gathering. It has weight. It pressed down over my scalp and made me feel like I had put my head under a tap. I took a breath to swallow it. I told them the number as a fact without embellishment. I said, “Two and a half years. That is enough time to do something human,” and I watched people translate that word into their own kitchens.

I talked about hubs like benches in a park where you go when you are lost or waiting for the person you love. I said, “Go to the place with caged basketball hoops and melting red punch stains on the floor. Go to the place with a stage where the children once argued about who gets to be a tree. Go to the place with a freezer in the back that always squeals. If you don’t know where that is, ask a kid. They always know.” I told them to bring water and a notebook and the names of their elders and the medications in their cabinets and their recipes for cheap food that tastes rich. I said, “Bring a neighbor you are not sure you like. This will be the hardest part and the most important.”

I said that the angels were not kings. I said that they would sing and show us where not to step, and we would take the steps. The crowd looked up and I held their looking by naming the looking. I told them that power would try to dress itself in their fear and we should be generous without being stupid. I said that we would count and we would measure because numbers make bridges when spoken softly. I said that we would be wrong and we would not settle there.

When I said the word planets out loud, a ripple went through the square like wind passing over scythed wheat. The word made some people look beautiful; it made others look murderous. I told them that planets was not a pretty word today, it was a shopping list word. I told them we would send instruments first because we are a species that pokes with sticks before putting our arms in, and that is wisdom. I said that if we went we would not do it like thieves in a museum, palming artifacts. We would bring seeds and apology. We would bring our bad jokes. We would bring the recipes we learned from a grandmother who never measured anything and still always made it taste like a story. We would ask permission. We would write our names in pencil.

A shoe flew. It was a loafer with a heel worn thin on one side, and it went end-over-end like a coin trying to pretend to be an idea. It hit the podium, not me, and the applause that followed was not applause, it was the sound people make when an object falls and does not kill. Tam moved before I did, a swift, precise reconfiguration of body and intent, and she did not move toward the man because she does not believe in being a wall when you can be a door. She found his eyes. He was already crying because anger, too, is a salve for fear until it isn’t. I said into the wide open sky, “Keep throwing shoes if you have to; we’ve all worn something that didn’t fit,” and a laugh rose like steam. It wasn’t pretty. It was necessary. The man’s shoulders dropped. He put his hands in his pockets and pulled them out empty as if to confess he had been hoping they were full all along.

After that the words came easier because the hardest thing had already happened and I had not died. I told them when, where, how to gather. I told them to take their money out of mattresses only as far as to buy a hand-crank radio and dried beans, and then put the money back if they had any left because the future we are not yet in still needs buses and show tickets and tips. I told them we were not closing but opening, like a hand, and that opening would hurt because we had used those fingers to hold onto ourselves for so long. I told them what we needed: translators who like puzzles, engineers whose first tool was a coat hanger, nurses who can start IVs in rolling ambulances, kids who are good at finding batteries in drawers. I said, “If your specialty is cooling temper tantrums in grocery store aisles, bring that. If your specialty is coaxing seeds that look like commas into basil like paragraphs, bring that. If your specialty is apologizing to people you don’t want to apologize to and meaning it, bring that twice.”

The angels hummed in a way that did not ask for acknowledgment and got it anyway. When I ended, there was no crescendo. There was a wave of bodies turning to talk to other bodies, which is what happens when humans hear something that fits. We make group work out of it. A teen somewhere shouted, “Let’s go,” and the crowd moved without stampeding, a miracle I will not claim credit for. Holm grabbed my elbow with the grip of a person clinging to a rope, and Sana pressed a thermos into my hand, and Tam exhaled so hard I felt it cool the edge of my jaw.

The next room after the square was a room that smelled like toner and worry. Tables. Maps. The maps were already wrong because the river was thinking about a new shape for itself like a child thinking about telling a lie. Holm had people moving pushpins like prayers. Sana was already on the phone with a glacier in another time zone. The linguist, Dana, slid up with a sheaf of music paper she had stolen from a marching band closet. She had translated pieces of the songs the angels gave us into notation that looked like something you’d play only if you wanted your instrument to develop opinions. Kieran rolled in a whiteboard and wrote on it with a marker that squealed until he apologized to it under his breath.

“We can build a chamber,” he said, to no one and everyone. “Not a portal. An ear. A room that is a bell. We ring the song and see what listens. If the air presses or the temperature hums a notch sideways, if a smell no one remembers naming opens, we write that down. We don’t put anybody in there. We don’t put a bug in there. We put metal and math. I take that back; we put a leaf in there because leaves are brave.”

“An ear,” Sana said, liking it. “Ears we can make. Ears we can build in basements if we have to. Ears don’t require a vote from a budget committee. Ears become maps.”

Velez straightened imperceptibly, a geometry hearing a metaphor it could occupy. “Do not make a mouth by accident,” it said. “Do not make a door that swings only one way. We will sing you away from that kind of hinge if you listen.”

Holm wrote HUBS on a whiteboard with a slash between the letters, as if making the word into a command. Underneath she wrote a list so plain it could have been a grocery list: Water. Food. Shade. Heat. Power, ankle height first. People who know the block. Wheelchairs. Insulin. Whistles. Tape. Pens that write upside down. Dignity, underlined twice even though she may have meant it as a joke. I watched people bring their own handwriting to the table, hats still on because they forgot about their heads in the face of a larger one.

I made a rule nobody asked me to make and then realized it was the only way I could stand to be in this kind of room. I said, “No acronyms,” and Holm laughed and then put a line through a string of letters she had been composing. “We will lose people at the second capital,” I said. “We will keep the doors open if each word fits inside the mouth of a person who hates meetings.”

Jun arrived with a backpack that looked like it had been packed by a person who understands the difference between a hypothetical and a hallway. He brought lemons and index cards and tape with the good pull. He hugged me as if he were handing me a rope. His eyes were tenderized meat. “I made a form,” he said, not embarrassed because shame was suddenly too expensive. “Names. Skills. The thing you do without thinking when your phone dies. The tallest thing you can carry down three flights of stairs without stopping. The name of the neighbor you’d call at two a.m. If they don’t have one, we help them find one.”

“You’re a monster,” I said, because sometimes you honor genius with a joke.

He set up at a corner table and became a lighthouse; people came and he turned their fear into lines in a spreadsheet that breathed. He asked them questions like a barber or a bartender or a rabbi, which is to say kindly and with a hand on the shoulder at the exact right second. He made eye contact the way you hold a nail while you hammer it.

We built the first ear in a drained community pool that had chipped blue paint the color of longing. The pool had resisted becoming a skate park for years and now it got to be something larger. Volunteers taped plastic across the windows until the room felt like inside a throat. We built a frame of pipe and tension cable and hung sheets welded with mesh and a material Sana called meta, as if we could better reality by saying the word out loud. We hung resonant plates we stole from a piano that had been left out on the sidewalk in the weather and refused to die. We borrowed microphones from the city’s least-bad cover band and a speaker stack that teenagers had previously used to annoy their parents and now was asked to annoy the gap between worlds.

Dana stood in the center with a pitch pipe and a laptop that had survived three majors. She ran a hand through short hair and made a face like she was about to taste something sour on purpose. The angels ringed the rafters like sentences that hadn’t found their verbs. Velez made a small motion with its width that I had learned was yes in angel. People in orange volunteer vests whispered to each other the way people speak at wakes.

“On three,” Dana said, and then didn’t count because real beginnings never do. She lifted the pitch and the sound was small and real and human, the way a whistle is, the way a kettle is, the way a mother calling a kid who is just out of sight is. She braided in the next note and the next, and the chords didn’t sound like chords until your ribs remembered something from any time you had ever been held. The sheets in the frame shook without moving. The temperature did something you could have written in a notebook if your notebook had a column for this next weather.

It smelled like pennies and peach skin and wet bark, which made the hair on my arms stand up because sometimes repetition is proof and sometimes it is warning. The blue paint on the pool wall looked greener for a second and then remembered what it was. Kieran watched a needle climb a gauge and then laughed at a spot on the curve that made him see an old friend. He whispered, “It’s a reply,” and then covered his mouth as if it were blasphemy to be that glad.

We did not put anything alive in the ear. We soldered a loop of wire and clipped it to a ring soaked in sugar water and watched the water bead and then fall in a pattern none of us had the math for. We rusted pieces of steel that had asked for it for years. We left a square of silk and it came back smelling like a bread we didn’t know how to bake. We wrote everything down in three separate notebooks in three different hands because redundancy is a kind of faith.

Later, in the ten o’clock meeting—or maybe it was the two; time was a sliding window—I said the words no angels, no armies, not because I believed either could be banned but because I needed to hear them said near each other so we could feel the current that would jump between. A man in a uniform bristling with rectangles of color stood and tried to make a rectangle of me. He said chain of command and I said command makes chains if you forget why you needed the chain in the first place. He said contingency operation and I said waterline. He said triage and I said kids. He looked at Tam like he was trying to find permission and she looked at his boots and did not give it. Holm refused to be the kind of politician who uses words like partnership when she means oversight; she said, “We’ll need trucks, Major. Not speeches,” and to his credit the man nodded and left his rhetoric on the chair and went to find keys.

The names began as a rumor. The angels, in their awkward kindness, had brought a list of people who could hold two truths at once without dropping either. The list was not a hierarchy, it was a constellation. One name was a woman who taught dance in a rec center and repaired zippers between classes. One was a man who ran an after-hours soup line out of a legally ambiguous kitchen. One was a librarian who could make a room quiet without being cruel. There were not leaders the way we expect them; they were conduits. They were markers in the old sense: things you put down so you don’t lose the way. The angels called them witnesses but we called them what we could live with. We called and they said yes the way people say yes to carrying a crate they have not looked inside yet.

Nights got bad around three a.m. when the city’s hums thinned and your own thoughts made larger sounds. The angels sang outside my window and once a neighbor shouted Shut up because grief is not polite. I made notes on a pad beside the bed and woke to sentences that looked like somebody else’s handwriting. Jun fell asleep at the kitchen table twice and once we just covered him with a coat and wrote around him. Tam would leave and come back with paper and salty snacks and the kind of milk that never goes bad and face wash, because two and a half years is a long time to be without good soap. Sana started using new words: resonance window, dampening, braid integrity. Holm learned the names of the night-shift janitors at City Hall and said them aloud so often you would think she was incanting, and maybe she was.

I went back to the course when I shouldn’t have, the way you go back to a place that used to be only yours in order to make a small bargain with yourself. The putting green was a study in footprints, foreign weights pressed into the soft. The sign warning about aeration looked like it was trying to apologize for all of creation. In the pro shop the counter still had the little paper basket of cheap tees with bad jokes printed on them like embarrassment. Colin’s mug had gone cold and then dried and then acquired a ring that made me think about time in a way that made me want to sit down. I took the shopping list he’d left under the magnet—cabbage, rice, paper towels, something crossed off I can’t read—and stuck it in my pocket not because I wanted a relic but because this was how I could carry him. An angel touched my cheek and I felt the exact tenderness of someone adjusting a collar before you walk into a room you’d hoped to avoid.

“Tell me a thing I cannot know until later,” I said to Velez outside, and he laughed without cruelty.

“On a night you will not expect,” it said, “the stars will look like they are turning backward. That is a fold rehearsal. Stay inside even if you think that is cowardice. Your breath will feel like it wants to run away. Hold it softly. If you must sing, sing to quiet your bones, not the sky.”

“What else,” I said, because greed is not only for food and money; it is for certainty too.

“Ships,” it said, dimming. “Do not build them with corners that hunger for status. You will be tempted to paint names on the sides before you know if they float. Paint the word try. Then paint nothing. Then send the first ones empty if you can. Do not strap the poor to a rocket and call it salvation. Do not strap the rich either and call it justice.”

That night a man with a blowout haircut got on a television and said my name like it had cut him and he wanted to make it bleed. He said golfer like it was a slur. In the comment flood that I didn’t read but felt across my skin anyway, people put me in every painting and on every cereal box and under every headline like glue. Jun printed the memes and taped them to the wall because he believes in demystifying joke ghosts. Tam drew mustaches on the cruelest ones because she believes in defacement as balm. I threw a paper plane of myself down the hallway and watched it crash into a pile of blankets and felt better than was logical.

We opened the first hub in the gym with the scuffed lines and the clock that had not worked in years but still presided like a judge pretending retirement. Volunteers in vests that matched nothing handed out clipboards and crayons and water. A woman with a beautiful face that had been stern for too long showed up with a bag of mismatched socks and became the sock person, which was not her destiny but it was her day. A boy crawled under the bleachers and came out with a kitten and a handful of broken wishes he blew at me like confetti. An old man stood at a corner table and sharpened pencils with a pocket knife, shavings like curled paper rain. A girl explained to her grandmother that the angels were not ghosts because ghosts do not smell like rain on pennies. A crew that had been a youth basketball team before their coach fell asleep sitting up made sandwiches with mustard like a deadline.

The Major came back with trucks and the stiff posture that says being told to help has injured something tender. Tam handed him a stack of clipboards without ceremony while Holm told him which door to guard and which to wedge open with a piece of wood because the wedge was missing. Sana set up a station for insulin like she had been born knowing where to put coolers so they don’t trip anyone. Dana sat with a group of kids and showed them how to write the song shapes with crayons, not because they needed to but because doing a thing you can do with your hands near a thing you cannot do with your hands is medicine. The priest put a basket by the door and wrote on it in black marker FOR PHONES WHILE YOU CRY and people used it and nobody stole any and that made me believe in something I do not like to name.

It wasn’t clean. It wasn’t orderly. It was a kind of music anyway. I stood on the stage and did not speak because the room did not need me to tell it what it was. A woman came up with a notebook already full because she is the sort of person who has been making hubs in her building since forever. She wanted a stamp. She wanted a version of official. I drew a small circle on her page with a smile inside it and she nodded and we both pretended it was a badge so we could keep walking.

Late, after the chairs had been stacked by teenagers with energy like sparks, after the floors had been swept with push brooms that left a whisper trail, after someone had taken the leftover sandwiches and listed who they would go to and how to get them there without waking babies, I walked home with Tam and Jun. The city had the softness of a person who has been crying for a while and is now making tea. We passed a man playing a violin under a bridge who had tuned it to the angel hum and was making money hand over fist which he put meticulously into a pocket and then took out and handed to a woman with a sign that said SHEEPISHLY: RENT. We passed a building that had a light on in one window and nothing in the room but two chairs and a plant and two people telling the truth to each other in a way you could feel through brick.

Jun dropped a lemon and it rolled into the curb and he chased it and then stopped and looked at me and we laughed in that exhausted way that feels like a relief valve opening on a factory you used to hate but now requires because it keeps the lights on. Velez hovered near the streetlight like an extra bulb. I wanted to ask it to go away and I wanted it to stay and I told it neither thing because choosing is exhausting and I have learned to save that muscle for when I need it.

At home, my table wasn’t big enough for the important papers now, so we put important papers on the floor and on the bed and under the plant and on the windowsill and in the sink for a minute while I washed my hands very thoroughly because my mother’s ghost still believes in soap. I wrote Hello. I am a person. We have a plan again on a pad because sometimes handwriting your own script into yourself is the only way to allow that your mouth said the thing. This time the period at the end looked heavier, as if gravity had upped its insistence by one small notch we could withstand so long as we didn’t pretend we couldn’t feel it.

The thunder that came was not storm but infrastructure, a construction sound from outside the city where they were building a temporary bridge over a piece of river that had gotten ideas. It sounded like paper folded with purpose. It sounded like a boat being born from flat. It sounded like something we were going to ask people we love to step into, hand in hand, without knowing where the shoreline was going to present itself on the other side. I poured water into glasses and handed them to my people and put my own glass down too close to a map and smeared a line and then apologized to the map out loud because I have turned into that kind of person. We slept in shifts with the angels three degrees off our windows and the city breathing through its teeth and the clock over the gym being wrong on purpose as a kindness to us all.

Chapter 5

The night the sky practiced breaking, the city learned to hold still. It wasn’t even a night in the calendar sense; it was one of those in-between hours with day still clinging to the edges, enough light in the west that the pigeons hadn’t given up yet. We were in the gym hub taking stock of things with labels, and then all at once every conversation leaned the same way because something at the top of us had turned its head. People went outside in clumps—curiosity is a herd animal—and then froze in doorways when the stars did the thing they do in bad renderings, the wrongness inserted on purpose so you’ll notice. They slid, not quickly but wrong-speed, like a clock hand being pushed by a child. A man said aloud to an empty patch of bleachers, “That’s not possible,” and then sat down and put his head in his hands before the sentence finished. Someone laughed because that is what fear does when backed into a corner. A woman clapped her hands once like she was calling a dog, and then covered her mouth as if she had woken something.

We had told them to stay inside if the sky paraded. We had told them the parade was not for us. We had taped notes to the doors like you tape a reminder to a fridge: three lines in black marker, the ink bleeding a little because the paper was cheap. Stay inside. Breathe so your bones hear. Sing if you must. People read it and then read it again and then did not believe it until belief was easier than standing exposed with your hair lifted by a wind you couldn’t find. Tam put her palm at the back of my ribs where the breath gets stuck and counted, one-two-three-four, her voice so steady it made me feel like I was in a boat that did not know the word capsize. Jun’s spreadsheet got forgotten for ten minutes, which is a catastrophe in his world, and he stood staring at nothing except everything, then blinked hard and went around closing windows because sometimes the best thing you can do for a city is become the person who closes things that were opened too far.

The sound, when it came, did not come through ears. Velez had said bones and I had assumed he meant it metaphorically, but bones have ownphones we’ve just never been made to answer before. It was a tone like someone dragging a finger around a wineglass that had been growing at the same temperature as the ocean. It said, Hold. It said, Stay. It said, You are not fragile but you are not in charge. The worst of us went outside to point guns at the sky because ritual is hard to quit. The best of us put hands on knees and remembered how to persuade the body to continue. A kid under the bleachers started humming and then someone hummed with him and then the whole left side of the gym was a chorus, low and ridiculous and perfect, the way people singing always is when they’re not performing for money.

When it passed, it didn’t. It changed shape and weight and slid into a different room of the body. We crept to windows and decided not to look straight up yet, the way you get out of bed and do a lap of the hallway before confronting a mirror after you’ve cried. The stars remembered themselves in a rush, as if embarrassed, and people began to talk like air being let out of something. Someone made a joke about retrograde and the astrologer in the corner rolled her eyes in a way that told me she would tell a better joke later when she had her breath back. I found Velez by not looking for it and felt it like the pressure at the back of a closed door. It made the little motion that means yes without showing off, which is a skill angels are only now learning.

“Rehearsal,” it said, arranging light like somebody smoothing a collar. “Not for you. For the fold. It is learning its bad manners.”

“You said to sing to our bones, not the sky,” I said, and my voice sounded like something that needed oil. “We sounded ridiculous.”

“You sounded correct,” it said. “Ridiculous is a kind of correct that keeps you alive.”

Out in the square beyond the gym, a man shouted that this was a sign of salvation and tried to sell candles at a markup. Holm walked over with a look on her face like, Of course, and bought every candle and then handed them out for free and called him honey when he sputtered. Sana sat on the floor with her back against the wall and wrote three pages of notes about what instruments she didn’t have that she wished she did and then circled the words cheap accelerometer twice. Kieran ran outside and spun slowly while staring, then swayed and sat down and said, “Okay then,” to the concrete. Dana covered her ears and took them off and covered them again and I loved her for the honesty of indecision.

By midnight the city was tired of pretending it could make the sky behave through observation alone. People went home, or to new homes built inside the bones of old schools, and cooked noodles on hot plates and told stories of former nights that had felt like the end just to make this one feel like part of a parade float of endings instead of a knife point. I slept early for six minutes and dreamed that my driver had grown hair and was humming in my bag. Tam shook me awake softly and handed me a sandwich that had so much mustard on it it felt honest. Velez hummed outside a window the way a bee will hover a second too long to be polite, and then dimmed so we could all pretend we were only a building with a gym in it, not a lung with a city wrapped around it.

In the morning the news tried to name the thing that had happened and failed three times and then settled on a word that meant nothing and felt safe in the mouth, and I forgave them because making language was a bucket and at least they were carrying. The pundit with the hurricane haircut said my name like it had a handle he could turn and asked whether women who hit balls for a living were qualified to advise on geophysics, and then a woman from the earthquake office with a face like a cup of coffee answered, “Yes,” without looking up because she was busy making a list of buildings that needed their spines checked. The internet divided into jokes about retrograde and diagrams amplified until they turned to chalk dust. The angels did not explain. They went in groups to nursing homes and sat outside windows and made the kind of light that doesn’t ask for thank you.

The ears gave us a reply that afternoon and we were not ready for it because we had told ourselves that answers only come when you’re holding instruments properly. The drained pool had become our favorite mistake; it read as silly to anyone who believed that science wore only clean coats. The teenagers who had spray painted their names inside it years ago now stood on the deck pressing their hands into their pockets and watching like they’d been asked to babysit a very expensive toddler. We began humming the song we’d been given for Place One, which we had not named yet because names make false ownerships, and the room did its temperature trick and then something smaller and meaner: a metallic smell like coins between teeth, and then a curl of scent over that like resin or the first cut you make into a sap-bleeding tree.

Kieran had set up a grid of sensor plates and sugar water loops and a piece of silk over a ring like a cheap toy magic trick. A bead formed on the silk that was not condensation in the usual sense because the temperature in the room did not support it and there was no source we could point to with a finger that would satisfy a teacher. The bead fell, and I knew when it hit the plate that we had to slow time as much as possible without becoming statues. Sana moved like a chess piece and I watched gratitude become a weapon in her hand. She scooped the drop with a glass tip and set it into a vial and labeled it with her handwriting that looked like someone had taught her to write in the middle of a chase scene. She handed the vial to a kid who was suddenly a courier in a movie and he ran as if the hallway were a track with both ends on fire.

We had promised ourselves and each other that we would not breathe anything we didn’t understand just because it used the shape of our longing. We had the fume hood and the sterilizer that smelled faintly like hospitals and grandparents. The first test Sana did was so simple I wanted to kiss her: she warmed the droplet near a clean wire and watched whether the smoke went up or refused to be smoke. It went up, which meant we’d stayed in our own air. No alien pathogens, at least not on the part of our chart where we could make notes. She did three more things with the same slow hands and then looked up and smiled in a way that told me a big thing: someone had stood at a cliff and not fallen and she had witnessed it.

“It’s resin-ish,” she said, finding a word that wasn’t in any categorized smell list. “Low salt. Trace something that reads as pine if pine had been taught a new trick. Something that hums like chalk when you scratch a plate but for noses.” She stopped and huffed at herself and I loved her for her attempts to make poetry serve data because the reverse had been happening to us all week and it was only fair. “There’s oxygen in the way we like it in our lungs, but that could be bias. It’s like we told the air a story about what we wanted and it nodded halfway.”

“Lake,” I said without meaning to, and then I was embarrassed because it felt like I was naming a baby at a grocery store by pointing at whatever I could see. “I mean the summer smell where for an hour the mosquitoes forget to exist. I mean that. It’s in there.”

“It’s in there,” Dana said, and she didn’t look up from her chart where she had made new symbols because the old ones had run out. “This is the part where we argue about who gets to choose the word, and then we decide no one gets to choose the word until we find the place with our feet, if we ever do. Until then we call it by numbers and songs and something we can’t ruin with our ownership.”

The teenagers started calling it Blue Two because the paint had once been blue and the second vial had been slightly darker, and I felt dizzy with relief at being spared a myth for five minutes. We put the vial in a cooler as if it were human and carried it to a place where it could get translated into numbers that would make Kieran exhale like a relieved window. The angels watched without comment in their way that is not detached so much as protective of our right to pretend we had thought of it all. Velez leaned toward me until my hair lifted and said a thing that rang true and annoyed me: “You will get addicted to small good news,” it said. “Ration it like sugar. It makes the rest possible but it will rot your optimism if you chug.”

The Major came back with new shoulders. He had taken off the jacket that advertised his rank and put on one that just said his name, ARROYO stitched small and almost not there. He brought trucks and people who had spent their lives wanting to be given tasks they could complete with their hands and timelines. He found me making a list with bad pen on worse paper and waited awkwardly to be told he could speak, even though I had never once asked him to wait to speak. “My kid,” he said, and he did not add a verb, which is how you know a man is not practicing. “She came to the hub last night because she was with her mom and they thought it was just… a warming station. She slept on a yoga mat and woke up when the sky—” and he moved one hand in a circle that meant the word none of us had. “She said a woman sang and it made her chest stop hurting.”

“That woman is fourteen,” I said because we had the list of who hummed and when because we write everything down when we think we might forget later that we were brave. “We’re feeding her pancakes for the rest of her life.”

He nodded and did the thing where a man wipes his eye like he’s adjusting his face. “Tell me what to guard and what to ignore,” he said, and the humility in it broke something tender in me that I hadn’t realized I was armoring. “I have people good at doors. They need better doors.”

“Guard the ear rooms,” I said. “Guard the insulin without making people feel like you’ll shoot them to protect their medicine; stand there like an uncle. Ignore the people selling candles until they sell knives with the candles. And if anyone says the words body count, put them in a corner like a toddler and don’t let them talk in public until they remember how to say people.”

“Copy,” he said, and meant it in the radio way, which was fine because every language gets to borrow. “And about the team from the—” He stopped and smiled at himself. “About the guys in suits who want to requisition your hubs for continuity of government. They’re in the lobby. They don’t like my face when I am polite.”

Holm appeared like the manifestation of his sentence with her hair doing the thing it does when hats have been asked of it and refused. She had a stack of forms that said REQUEST on the top and a pen that had given up three times and had teeth marks that looked new. “We have to work with them,” she said, and we all made faces because adults rarely get to be purely righteous. “But they don’t get to rename what we already built. No acronyms,” she added, and it and I laughed because I love a rule that propagates in the wild.

We went to the lobby and shook hands with men who wore their watches heavy and their shoes quiet. They used the word theater like an accusation and I used the word staging like a bridge and after ten minutes we all agreed that there would be a table in the corner where someone from their world could sit and take notes and be useful without owning the furniture. They wanted to know how we would keep order if people didn’t listen, and I said, “We will listen first,” and they blinked like someone had thrown cold water in their faces. One of them tried to hand me a binder with tabs that said things like FOOD AUTHORITY and INCIDENT ESCALATION, and I took it from him because refusing a binder is bad optics when cameras are near, and then handed it to Jun without looking and Jun put it under a potted plant and smiled sweetly until the camera left.

The mouth almost happened and then didn’t, and the part of me that believes in luck as a species of genius will put that day on a small shelf forever. We had said ear so often that we thought we were safe from our own hunger to pry, but metaphors are slippery. A private lab out by the beltway, a building with mirrored glass that made it look like it wanted to spy on itself, started vibrating on someone else’s channel. An engineer who loved machines more than rules had built a chamber that did two things at once and he was so proud he wanted to be forgiven in advance. The song had bent in their room, and then there had been a moment of thinned air like the breath you hold when you pass someone crying on a bus, and then a smell that wanted to be called meat. A tech with a hair tie around her wrist had texted a friend at a hub while her boss went to find a tie; the friend texted a friend; the friend texted Holm; Holm texted me; I texted Velez even though that is not how it works and the reply was a light at the edge of my vision that made me step backward without deciding to.

We went in a van because sometimes the future still arrives in vans that smell faintly of French fries. Arroyo brought two of his door people, who had door eyes but hearts not yet crushed by door work. Holm wore a blazer like armor and flats like a concession. Sana brought the tone generator in its padded case, which looked like a violin and felt just as sensitive to insult. Tam drove because she trusts only her hands when urgency is in the car. We didn’t have a warrant of any kind and also this is not a story where warrants matter; we had the arrogance of being right and the backup of languages we could switch to mid-hallway to confuse a man with a lanyard.

The building’s guard looked like a person who had once believed in rules and now believed in shift change. He tried to tell us to stop and Holm said, “Minister,” and didn’t flash a badge because we hadn’t made those yet, and he stepped aside because people love titles even as they claim not to. Inside we could hear a hum that wasn’t on any of our lists of okay hums. The chamber had been welded from steel that had wanted to be a boat twenty years ago, and it sat in a room with too many wires and too little sense. A man with eyes like a raccoon on day four of a thesis defense tried to convince us we were lucky to witness his first success, and Sana said, in the quiet voice that breaks arrogance quicker than shouting, “Turn it off or we leave and take out your breakers.”

The tech with the hair tie looked at me and made teeny finger gestures that meant, Please be the adult in the room that I can’t afford to be, and I felt my heart put on a uniform I had not issued, which is something hearts do when told they are in charge. “You are building a mouth,” I said. “You are building a door with a bias. You are calling it a window so you can sleep. Turn it off.”

“We are on a deadline,” he said, which is the scariest sentence a scientist can say to me now.

“So is the Earth,” Tam said, and I loved her for the way she can throw a sentence like a brick into a stack of red cups. “Nobody is trying to beat the apocalypse to the finish line by cheating on a test.”

Sana stepped in and laid a hand on the tone generator case like a parent resting a hand on a sleeping child. “We will give you an ear,” she said, and the man flinched at the word choice because ears imply listening equals humility. “You can have sensor time. You can have math. You cannot have a mouth yet. You cannot build a hinge that only swings one way and hope the air doesn’t notice.”

Arroyo had already begun unplugging things with the skill of a man who understands that electricity is a kind of badly behaved river. He pulled a cord gently and then another, and the hum dimmed a shade and I could feel my teeth uncurl. Velez glowed so bright in the corner that the tech muttered whoa without meaning to, and then put both hands on the table like she was steadying a patient. The raccoon-eyed man put his face in his hands and did not say sorry, which was fair because he was not sorry; he was thwarted. I recognized the feeling and despised it and offered him a job he didn’t want yet in three weeks when he would come looking because this is how you steal brilliance back from hunger.

After, in the van, Holm laughed so hard it scared me, and then she cried in one breath like a faucet with a weight on the handle, and then she said, “We need a pipeline for whistleblowers that isn’t just teenagers texting their cousins,” and Jun, who had come because he can sense when a spreadsheet is going to need a new column, wrote the word WHISTLES in all caps on the top of a page and then softer beside it wrote the words cookies and parking validation because he is the only person in the city who understands that justice requires snacks and a place to put your car without being ticketed.

We named the first place accidentally, which I should have expected given that all the best names are like that. The vial had a label in Sana’s hand and a smudge from my thumb where I’d been careless, and the smudge made a streak that looked like a small mountain seen from far away on a map drawn by a child. Dana pointed at it and said, “Ridge,” and then shook her head because she didn’t want to be the one to say it first. Arroyo said, “Tone,” because he was reading the graph Kieran had printed and taped badly to a wall. Jun, without looking, said, “Ridgetone,” and the room said it back to itself and then frowned because it was ugly and therefore likely to stick. We decided to call it that and not in public, to give ourselves a place to stand that the internet didn’t own. The teenagers hated it and started a poll to rename it Lakeward, which was better and worse, and I shrugged because fighting over a nickname is how you get people to show up to a meeting they didn’t want to go to.

I went back to the course because there are only so many hours you can ask a body to hold responsibility without giving it a familiar ritual to wash its hands in. It was not my day, it was no one’s day, and still the fairways had people scattered the way a small town scatters at a fair. They were not swinging clubs and the sight of that made me exhale in a way I could trust. They were walking the lines we had all walked before when none of this had happened and saying to each other, “This is where she sliced once,” and “This is the stupid bunker that ate her,” and “This is where I dropped my keys and found them because a stranger had noticed,” which is a ritual and a kindness in equal measure. The bunker on seventeen still sat like an old idea that used to be fun. The angels were further out that day, hovering above the treeline like a punctuation mark waiting for a sentence to earn it.

Colin’s shopping list was in my pocket and I took it out and read it again because there is a certain holiness in inventory. Cabbage. Rice. Paper towels. Something crossed off that might be onions or might be a debt. I walked to the corner store and bought the items and then walked back to the course and left the bag on the counter of the pro shop where his mug was not, where his name was not, where the new kid behind the counter with a face like a second chance looked at the bag and then at me and said, “What is this,” and I said, “This is me doing a very small thing for a person who is very not here,” and he nodded like a man who has been given a blessing he didn’t request and will honor anyway.

Holm started sleeping on a cot in her office, not because she wanted to make a martyr out of her spine but because there was no other place to put the maps. Tam kept a list of who had gone home and who had not, and once I saw her add my name to the second column and cross it out and add it again and then draw a heart around it like a teenager, and I had to go into a stairwell and let my face do a thing that wouldn’t survive fluorescent light. Sana began collecting broken instruments—violins with hair missing, trumpets with stuck valves, a bass drum that had been kicked by a marching band with poor impulse control—and putting them in the ear rooms not to play but to listen, because she believed and made me believe that metal and wood remember things we don’t and might show us how not to be rude to physics. Dana learned how to sleep sitting up without falling over. Kieran started calling his mother more often and once I answered his phone because his hands were inside a wire harness and talked to a woman who said, “He was there when the creek flooded and he was eight and he made a dam out of sticks that held for an hour, did he tell you,” and I said, “He will,” and she said, “He will not,” and we hung up both satisfied.

People asked me to go to their meetings and I learned quickly how to be two in a day before noon. A group in a church basement with coffee in urns and a smell like old books wanted to talk about what the beginning of leaving would look like because the leaving was a rumor nobody trusted and an obligation everybody dreaded. A group in a park wanted to be told they were vital and were, which is always a relief to be able to say honestly. A group in a warehouse wanted permission to build little things that look like boats out of truck tires and faith, and I said yes because they were not putting people in them, they were putting hope in them and rolling it around to see if it leaked. A group in a rich living room wanted to donate without having to come to the hub and I told them where to send money and then told them to show up anyway and bus tables with their soft hands for three hours because money is important and so is the sound a rich person makes when they realize the bread smells the same no matter who slices it.

The blowout hair man got a crowd to chant my name like an extinction event and I found the clip by accident when a volunteer’s phone fell on play. He said things about expertise that would have made sense to me when I was twenty-two and still believed we should only be led by people with laminated cards, and then he said something that made the room behind my ribs go cold in a new way: he talked about triage like it was a sport. He wanted ships for the loyal and ships for the skilled and ships for the “clean,” and I said the word out loud in my kitchen and my rubber plant leaned away like even it could not stand that sound. Jun printed the transcript and marked through the words that would hurt us if they stuck, and wrote in the margin, We do not triage people. We triage tasks, and I kissed the top of his head when he wasn’t looking because if I had said the words out loud I would have made a speech and we were on a speech diet.

We wrote the code on a wall near the door to the gym with a marker that had seen too much. It was not a code like encryption; it was a code like a recipe. No mouths. No acronyms. No kings. Lists when needed. Stories when needed. Buckets always. We added a line that Dana insisted on and Sana seconded: Data belongs to the neighborhood first. It got messy immediately because neighborhoods are messy and data is greedy and I have made peace with the fact that most rules are just temporary walls to lean on while you tie your shoe. We added another line in a different hand because the wall was not our paper; it was ours: If a door opens one way, we walk away. If a door opens two ways, we put a person in it never, and a leaf first, and then a machine, and then possibly a rumor, and then maybe a person when we have learned the rumor by heart.

On a Thursday at a time that would once have been traffic and now was just motion, a bus driver named Lo brought two dozen people from the far side of the river to the hub because their church had burst with volunteers and they needed to overflow. She had a tattoo of an anchor on her wrist and the laugh of a person who had been told a fine and had paid it and had not cried in public once. She had a binder full of names and allergies and the number of a guy who had access to a freezer truck, and I looked at her and said the quiet part out loud, “You are on the list,” and she said, “What list,” because this is the kind of person she is. I told her about the witnesses and she swore and then said, “Fine,” because humility is a door and she knows which way to push.

We took the first instruments to the bridge the city was building in the wrong place because we didn’t have the right place yet. Engineers who had learned to be poets that week set up transponders that were not weapons on a span that was not done. They tilted panels to listen to the song in a way that made me feel like a father in a movie teaching a child to shave. The angels hovered out over the water and did not touch it because they were learning to make the hard choice not to be useful in ways that make us lazy. A woman from the chorus in the old church with the cracked nave stood and sang a phrase into the wind and the wind brought the sound back to her with an extra weight like it had picked up a coin. A boy balanced on the rail with frogs in his pockets and looked like a person I would have followed up a mountain. The song made a shadow on the water like a map you could only read if you could hold your breath.

“Not yet,” Velez said, because it had learned the rhythm of my questions, and I did not pretend I hadn’t asked.

At home that night Tam tried to teach me to sleep again. She put on a bad murder show that we had seen twice before and it worked for a quarter of an hour until someone said alibi like a poem, and then I sat up because the word backwards meant something about the fold and I couldn’t stand that my brain was now a spigot that never turned off. She put her hand on my chest and I performed breathing. We talked about a thing that wasn’t this for three whole minutes, which was as close to a vacation as we are allotted in this epoch. I told her a story about a tournament where the bathroom on the front nine had been haunted by a tampon dispenser that made a sound like a failing airplane and she laughed until she couldn’t breathe just right and then we both breathed right to fix it.
